SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the Governor-General Amendment Bill 1988, which provides for an increase in the salary of the Governor-General. The Bill operates upon a principle which was laid down by the Whitlam Government in 1974 that the Governor-General's salary should be dealt with in a non-party way, that the salary should recognised the importance and place of this high office, and that the appointment of the Governor-General should not depend on personal wealth or the availability of other income.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity, on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, to say that we adhere to those three principles. We do not intend in any way to criticise the provision of an adequate level of remuneration for the next Governor-General of Australia. We intend to maintain to the full spirit what was properly enunciated by the Whitlam Government in 1974, regrettably departed from on an earlier occasion by one of my predecessors in the office of Leader of the Opposition. But I do not intend to depart from what I regarded as an entirely proper statement made in 1974 by the former member for Werriwa, the then Prime Minister of Australia. The Governor-General should be properly remunerated. It is part of the Australian tradition that holding a high office such as Governor-General should not follow wealth or social privilege or social status. I am very happy in those terms to say that on behalf of the Liberal and National parties.

Because this Bill relates to the office of Governor-General, I take this opportunity of saying a few things about that office. It will be apparent from statements that I have made in recent weeks that I attach very great significance to the office. Not only is the occupant of that office the representative in Australia of the Queen and therefore the pinnacle of our constitutional structure, but the occupant of that office has responsibilities to discharge the duties of that office in a totally non-partisan, politically neutral and unifying fashion. I imagine it would be the wish of members on both sides of the Parliament that, whoever might occupy the position of Governor-General, those three principles should be rigorously adhered to. I certainly look forward to a rigorous adherence to those principles by all future occupants of the position of Governor-General.

I also want to say a few words about the current occupant of the position of Governor-General. I know that in the months ahead there will be other opportunities of a formal and informal kind for people in different walks of life in Australia to record their appreciation of the work that Sir Ninian Stephen and Lady Stephen have done as occupants of the office of Governor-General and the Governor-General's wife. I will not let this opportunity go by without expressing, on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, our profound respect for the dignified yet informal and friendly manner in which the present Governor-General has discharged his duties over the past 5 1/2 years.

I say that with some emphasis because part of the debate which is now behind us about the appointment of the next Governor-General has carried with it one unfair implication; that is, that in some way the current occupant of the office has been too formal and that the office needs to be subject to a process of greater democratisation. That is an unfair implication. I cannot think of a man who has more cleverly blended dignity with Australian egalitarianism than Sir Ninian Stephen has done over the last 5 1/2 years. Anybody who has been a guest of his could not but have been struck by his enormous dignity, his unfailing civility and his innate capacity to put people at ease. He has been a truly impartial occupant. I believe that I speak with great accuracy in saying that relations between the present Government and the Governor-General have been good, friendly and cordial, as they should be and as they were between the present Governor-General and the former Government-the Fraser Government-which recommended his appointment to Her Majesty the Queen.

In supporting this measure and making the point that we adhere scrupulously to those three principles laid down by the Whitlam Government in 1974, I take the opportunity-there will be other occasions of doing it-of not only stressing the great importance of the office of Governor-General but also saying that we believe the present occupant has been a remarkable blend of egalitarianism and dignity. Any suggestions in recent weeks that in some way that standard has not been achieved in the recent years is manifestly unfair to the Governor-General, untrue and ought, for the purposes of the public record on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, to be explicitly repudiated.

SPEECH.PARA: There shall be payable to the Queen out of the Consolidated Revenue fund of the Commonwealth, for the salary of the Governor-General, an annual sum which, until the Parliament otherwise provides, shall be ten thousand pounds.
The salary of a Governor-General shall not be altered during his continuance in office.

We may have to do something in the future about the sexist language in the Constitution and this continuing assumption that the Governor-General must be male. There is only one opportunity for the Parliament to vary the salary of the Governor-General. That is most appropriately done towards the end of the term of one Governor-General and before the following Governor-General takes his or her place.

It is interesting that the provision was made at the time of Federation for the salary of the Governor-General to be #10,000 because, at the same time, section 48 of the Constitution says that, until the Parliament otherwise provides, each senator and each member of the House of Representatives `shall receive an allowance of four hundred pounds a year'. I do not know how this erosion of parities has taken place. I suppose a number of incumbents of that office would have preferred that the parities be maintained, because if we were to establish the same relationship between those two salaries now the Governor-General would be earning $1 1/4m a year. However, I would like to have the opportunity to make reference to the incoming Governor-General, a person for whom I have great personal respect and affection. I am sure that I share that respect and affection with the vast majority of the Australian people. In the course of the period of this Government, Bill Hayden was Minister for Foreign Affairs until he resigned to accept the appointment as Governor-General designate. During that period, I do not think anyone would deny-I am sure that honourable members opposite would not deny-that Bill Hayden was responsible for lifting the level of respect in which Australia was held, for maintaining the respect for Australia in international fora, and for making sure that Australia's voice was heard. For me it is an honour to stand in this historic chamber as the elected representative of the people who reside in the Oxley electorate. This is truly a great privilege, but the greatest of all honours is to be here as a member of the Australian Labour Party. The Australian Labour Party is the only political party in Australia to-day which can claim to be truly national in character and outlook. It is the only political party which pursues policies designed for the greatest good for the majority of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: I think a number of people who have commented on the appointment of Bill Hayden as Governor-General have clearly indicated the nature of the humble beginnings which he had. Having left school, he went into the Public Service. He found that very uninspiring. He became a police officer and was a police officer at the time he was elected to the Parliament. He is a man with a great sense of humour, a raconteur, and he has a great repertoire of stories and anecdotes. He is good company, despite the fact that on many occasions he tends to be a bit of a loner. He enjoys company and he certainly contributes greatly to social company. When he was appointed Treasurer in June 1985 an article in the Canberra Times said:
The appointment of Bill Hayden as Treasurer is a personal triumph for one of the Labor Party's most enthusiastic and diligent Ministers.

He was interviewed by the Australian Financial Review. I will read part of that interview because I think it indicates that to a large extent Bill Hayden's achievements vindicate the position which he adopted throughout his life. That position is very much related to his own background and his own circumstances. He said:

My mother was born in Queensland, my father was allegedly born in Ireland. We've since discovered that he was born in America and was an illegal immigrant. He jumped a ship. He was a merchant seaman and apparently-the story is very cloudy-he absconded from a catholic seminary to go to sea. He worked as a piano tuner, with a small business in the Rockhampton area. He was busted in the depression, and I have a vivid recollection of him heading off early in the morning with his kit, chasing a bit of work door-to-door, and bringing the piano frames home on the old drop centre trams-the trammie would be abusing him, and he'd be abusing the trammie. I was always a very poor reader. I was a typical product of the deprived socio-economic background that I understand now but didn't then. There weren't many books in our home-we couldn't afford them. It was poor, that was all. Bloody poor.

In a sense his personal achievements, as I have suggested, have been a vindication of his determination to fight injustice and to pursue equity, to provide opportunities and to remove obstacles to human achievement. He committed and dedicated his life to the achievement and the pursuit of those objectives. Every kid in every working class home in Australia can be encouraged by Bill Hayden, Governor- General designate of Australia. He and his outstanding and gracious wife, Dallas, will bring credit to themselves, to the people of the Oxley electorate in Queensland, to Australia, and to the position of Governor-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the members of the Australian Labor Party for coming down from the rafters to listen to the debate. Look at them all leave. They do not like to hear the truth. We are debating the Australia Council Amendment Bill 1988, which was brought in by the departing Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch). The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australia Council Act. In effect, it picks up the recommendations of the report of the former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, known affectionately as the McLeay report, after our Deputy Speaker, Mr Leo McLeay; and it is titled Patronage, Power and the Muse. Broadly, the McLeay report focused on the Australia Council and recommended a streamlining of the administrative structure and that the Council should take account of government policies at the Commonwealth, State and local government levels. The Australia Council broadly supported these recommendations, and thus the Bill gives effect to them. The Bill relates primarily to the functions of the Australia Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental question before the House today is whether these amendments adequately address the problems that exist with the Australia Council method of funding the arts. From this side of the House, we answer that question in the negative. Therefore, we will oppose this Bill. We will also move an amendment, about which I will speak at the committee stage and which has been circulated to honourable members. We do not agree that the Bill streamlines the Australia Council. Our fundamental objection is the continued bureaucratisation of the arts funding-and that has become the hallmark of the Australia Council. Far from solving the problem, the McLeay report, although it recognised it-and that, I think, can be said in its favour-really wanted us to stay with the old Whitlam experiment, probably for nostalgic reasons. But it missed the opportunity to take a quantum leap forward to a far better method. As for the far better method, it will remain for my colleague the shadow Minister to outline at some future time. Suffice it to say that for the purposes of this debate and this Bill, we will oppose the Bill on that primary ground.

As I said, the net result of these amendments is to create another board, to be known as the Community Cultural Development Board, which will bring the number of boards under the Council to five. The Bill also gives to the Minister the power to appoint others, probably his friends, to this and other boards. Indeed, going back over the Australia Council's record, one sees that the former Minister, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), was criticised at some length in the past for appointing his friends to the Board. Of course, this Bill perpetrates that ability of a Minister to appoint people who are close to him and not necessarily people who are related to the arts relevant to those boards.

If I can divert slightly, Mr Deputy Speaker: I think the arts ministry is quickly becoming something of a rubbish bin for failed Ministers, and that is to be regretted. As some wag said the other day, it is probably becoming the holding room for retirement, with the prospect of the new Minister moving in. I think that is unfair, because the arts deserve much better. In my own role as science and energy shadow spokesman, I would say that I think science deserves a far better role and treatment from the Government. However, that is a debate for later in the day.

To the fundamental question in this country, `Do arts matter?', I think one must answer in the affirmative, because they most certainly do. In a paper circulated not so long ago by Senator Puplick, who is the Opposition spokesman on arts matters-a paper that I am sure the Minister is aware of and has seen-that very fundamental question is discussed. The basic question is whether we in Australia ought to be funding the arts in its various forms. I think that there is a strong bipartisan view that the answer is yes. But the argument is as to how we ought to be funding the arts and the best method by which to do it.

We on this side of the House do not believe that the Australia Council, even as amended by the Minister, is a satisfactory long term solution. Indeed, a former Opposition spokesman for the arts, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), said that the use of a statutory authority in this way was merely a political subterfuge to protect Ministers from having to make hard decisions which they are either unable to or unwilling to later articulate.
In relation to the importance of the arts, I shall quote from that paper by Senator Puplick, as I think it encapsulates the arguments with which all of us in this place would agree. He says this:

However there is no doubt that the arts tell us something about ourselves. They allow us to make statements about ourselves both individually and as a people. They make a statement about what we want to communicate to our fellow Australians and to the rest of the world about our Australianness. The need to communicate, and especially to communicate our passions and our emotions without violence is one of the most basic of human instincts. This is becoming increasingly important in a modern world where the lack of communication and the resort to violence (both personally and as state policy) as a means of expression are becoming tragically and all too increasingly common.

Art can allow us as individuals to express ourselves beyond ourselves and to do so on our own terms. It can give joy and inspiration to others. As such, it is worthy of public support by a variety of means.
In Australia we should seek artistic expression which is both unique to us as Australians and yet is also international in its dimension and its comprehensibility.

I think that all of us in this House would agree with that statement, because it is a fundamental that we would all accept. If one wants to look a little more closely at the arts industry and its effect on Australia in pure economic terms, one needs to go back, of course, to that Industries Assistance Commission document where this matter was detailed. However, at present, on estimates available, arts and arts-related industry constitute about $3.1 billion. It has more than 50,000 full-time workers, who earn over $1,000m in salaries and pay and who also are contributing towards the Treasury about $200m in personal income tax. There are some 30,000 practising professional artists in Australia, of varying types. Thus, the impact of the arts industry on our economy is significant, and we must recognise that. It is important to all of us.

It is true that the arts are a unifying force in Australian society. Their practise and their enjoyment cross all barriers and recognise no divisions of origin, background, race or class. Thus, a developed national identity and commitments to shared values are achievable. The development of the creativity of our talented people must be our priority.

Political decisions will be and must be made about arts funding-obviously about the amount available and the general direction of its expenditure. That is basically what this debate is about. This debate will be curtailed somewhat, but others in this debate will make mention of the direction of some of the funding involved. In the past, the Waste Watch Committee did a great deal of service for this country in highlighting some of the more excessive and extraordinary utilisations of taxpayers' funds. Unfortunately, we certainly saw that within the arts area. One would hope that does not happen again. Indeed, I will have a few comments to make a little later about that possibility. But there are many examples of the misdirection of taxpayers' funds in support of the arts. This Minister will not now have an opportunity to take advantage of the powers that are contained in this amendment, particularly those powers contained in proposed new section 6b under which the Minister will be able to give directions to the chairperson of the Australia Council. Perhaps the new Minister, the present Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), who I understand has a keen interest in the arts-I suppose that ought to be welcomed-will be able to keep a close watch over the allocation of funds within his jurisdiction.

As I was saying, in a democracy the political decisions must be made by the politicians and not the bureaucrats, and that is the essence of our objections and our reasons for opposing this Bill. We should be held responsible and accountable for the decisions we make or fail to make, and people in the arts ought not be entitled to some special exemption from the basic rule of democratic government, nor should public money provided for the arts be quarantined from the same degree of political decision making and accountability which is properly demanded in other areas of public expenditure or industry subsidy.

Approximately 60 per cent of public support for the arts comes through State governments. None of them operates politically on the arm's length principle. They all have Ministers of the arts in some form or another directly under ministerial control. It is only at the federal level that the arm's length funding becomes a sacred cow-and, indeed, it has become that over the years. Under this arrangement a close analysis reveals that the real beneficiaries of the funding have to be seen to be not the artists but the arts bureaucrats. I believe there could be great benefits to artists if the number of arts bureaucrats involved in the administration of the funding arrangements were reduced, at least to a greater extent than this amendment proposes.

It was interesting to go back over the record. Perhaps I may refresh the memory of honourable members and particularly of the Minister at the table. In the House of Representatives on 17 October 1985 the honourable member for Robertson, the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, had this to say in his first major ministerial statement:

Many of my critics are enthusiastic and uncompromising supporters of the `arm's length principle', as they proclaim it, when it suits them, yet have no hesitation in demanding my direct intervention when it does not.
He went on to say:

Governments are elected to govern; to make decisions. This principle of Ministerial responsibility is generally demanded of governments in Australia. In relation to the arts, the present legislative arrangements make it near impossible to achieve.
He also said:

The other major patrons in Australia are the State governments and private companies. Neither of these groups practise `arm's length funding'. . . . The present system, it can be argued, protects partial patronage and hides prejudice beneath a cloak of artistic integrity.

Yet what is the Minister doing today? I think he puts the arguments that I am putting-that arm's length funding perhaps ought to be something of the past. He is persisting with this present structure, albeit with some changes, which in some senses I suppose one would welcome. But, really, he is persisting with the general thrust of enhancing the role of the Chairman of the Australia Council, Professor Donald Horne.
I think it is worth honourable members being aware of the powers of direction that are going to be vested in the Minister. Proposed new section 6b (1) states:

Where the Minister is satisfied that it is desirable in the public interest to do so, the Minister may, by notice in writing to the Chairperson, give directions to the Council with respect to the performance of its functions or the exercise of its power.

It would appear at first blush that that is a normal embracing power to accrue to the Minister. But, of course, in reality that is not going to be the case. This Minister and the next Minister are going to be put in the position where they have between them and the arts community a continuing Australia Council with large bureaucratic and administrative powers. I think it does not go nearly far enough. It certainly does not answer the criticism of the position that the former Minister found himself in in 1985 when he had running battles with many within the arts community.

I suppose it is appropriate to make some comment about Donald Horne, whose term expires in December 1989. Donald Horne was appointed late in 1984, after Morris West and Gough Whitlam said no. I do not believe it would be in anyone's interest to have Neville Wran running science and Gough Whitlam running the arts in this country.

—You have nothing to say, do you?
—The honourable member for Grayndler is now interjecting. He also should read the transcript. I think it could be well worth reading.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to come back to the terms of the Bill.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was distracted. The Minister is obviously interested in the transcript as well. Donald Horne signalled a change in direction in arts funding in his inaugural speech in January 1985. I will quote from what he said then because I think it is reasonably significant:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is it not possible that the Australia Council, while still providing some support for the large organisations, should be somewhat in the van, especially concerned with encouraging the risky and the innovative, with providing support for creative individuals and innovative institutions, with experimenting with appreciation, access and participation programs . . .

This emphasis on innovative institutions experimenting with appreciation and participation programs led directly to the way-out funding most Australians found objection- able. I think Donald Horne swung the pendulum far too far when he took over the Australia Council. In a sense, this amendment seeks to bring it back, because the exposures by such bodies as the Waste Watch Committee, criticised though they were by the Government, have been accepted. What the Minister is trying to do is go on the path that his former Minister indicated was necessary-to put the decision making back in our hands and not to give it to the bureaucrats. In so doing, he is going to benefit the arts nationwide and not in any way detract from them.

Clause 10 of the Bill refers to the creation of the Community Cultural Development Board, the Chairman of which is to be Donald Horne. Again, this Minister and the new Minister must look very carefully at this, because we do not want the Community Cultural Development Board to become yet another vehicle for the funding of what Donald Horne described on day one in the job as the innovative institution experimenting with appreciation and participation programs. I think that must be watched particularly carefully.

It is interesting how people's views change. Recently my eye caught an article in the Australian by Gerard Henderson, a man who is well known to some of us in this place. He made this point, which I think even the Minister would accept, about how people change. The thrust of Mr Henderson's article was that a person who starts at the left tends to be heard more than if he starts perhaps from the middle ground or even from the right. It is interesting that the Minister started from the left and has now moved to the right, and that has accrued some personal benefit to him. I must admit that he is a far more sensible Minister for having made that transition. In any event, Gerard Henderson said this in his column in the Australian in this past week:

During the time that Donald Horne was associate editor of Quadrant and a defender of the Australian commitment in Vietnam he was not a high flyer in the media. But since the time Donald purchased his `maintain the rage' badge the sky has been the limit.

Indeed it has. Donald Horne seems to comment on all and sundry matters. Perhaps the House could advise him that he would be better off pursuing purely the arts issues and not delving into areas which really are of no concern to him.

Before concluding my remarks, and allowing time for my colleagues to speak, I want to make some comments about the Design Board concerns that many of us have. The Minister will be aware that his Press release dated 3 June states that the Design Board was removed and that a committee has been set up under Donald Horne which will review the design elements of art rather than have the broad design role that the former Design Board had. I understand that on the committee is one of Australia's leading architects, Mr Andrews, who was on the Design Board. The Design Board was a lot smaller than many of the other boards. I make the point that the Design Board is particularly important in terms of the overall approach to design in Australia. It is a pity that the functions of design have been split. Design, as it relates to art, will now be put under this special committee and design in relation to industrial type design and improvements now falls within the purview of the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Technology (Senator Button). Previously there was a one-stop shop for design and it is to be lamented that it has changed. Indeed, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories received a letter from the Institution of Engineers, Australia. That letter makes interesting reading and I will read a part of it because it encapsulates the concerns that many of us have:

The Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, has announced that the Australia Council will form a design committee to replace the Design Board. Such a committee will be concerned with `arts related aspects of design'.

The Institution of Engineers, Australia wishes to record its concern at this decision-a decision that must adversely affect the promotion of industrial design as a powerful tool in the sale of Australian technology overseas.

At a time when the Government is encouraging industry to face up to world competition by reducing protection it seems illogical to remove support mechanisms-such as the Design Board-that are already in place. The Institution strongly advocates the maintenance of these mechanisms and urges the Government to either reconsider its decision or ensure that industrial design is properly catered for elsewhere.

When I picked up the statement on science and technology yesterday, it was interesting to note that in the preface the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce talked about the need to support education, science and particularly engineering to meet the very challenges that the Institution of Engineers talks about. Indeed, the need to make us competitive and innovative and to develop markets to enhance our export economy was talked about in the preface. The Design Board, though small, played a very special role. I urge the Minister to watch the new Design Committee carefully. Perhaps we have made a mistake in getting rid of the Design Board. Far be it from me to suggest that we have another board but I think that we ought to look very carefully at the merits of the design industry in Australia in its broadest context.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you suggest?
—We were going to suggest that you comment later when we release our policy.
—No, we suggested something. What would you suggest?

—No, we will talk about it later. Another suggestion I make to the Minister is that there be a centre of excellence for design in Australia. In Tasmania we have a centre of excellence in aquaculture. But there is no centre of excellence for design. It is something that the Minister should pursue with his colleagues. More particularly, there are opportunities to pursue centres of excellence of design in particular areas such as furniture. If honourable members cast their eyes around this chamber and this building, they will see excellence in furniture design that perhaps is by far the best that Australia has ever seen. We want to maintain those abilities, those qualities of craftsmanship. Indeed, a centre of excellence in furniture and interior architecture is something that we could be developing in this country. There are many schools of architecture. A faculty of design in my area, the Institute of Technology in Launceston, Tasmania, may be a repository for such a centre. That is the direction in which we should be going.
—Tasmania?
—Tasmania contributes mightily to the export wealth of this country. We are the only State that has been a net exporter since Federation.
—When you come up here they say you are their best export.

—But they always have me back again. I think that in looking for a suggestion, this is something that the Minister could pursue. Indeed, the broader point is the important point. If we want to develop an export related economy, we need to pursue excellence in arts, which, in its broadest form, can benefit this country. We know of its economic benefits to this country. It is to be lamented that there has been a split of the arts related to design aspects and industrial related design aspects, if it means that the importance and the emphasis placed on design is to be lost.
