SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of rather interesting comments from the Opposition spokesman standing in for Senator Puplick. Obviously he did his work a little hurriedly because he got here too late for the debate. In fact, we could have been put in a rather ridiculous situation-except that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) called a quorum when the Opposition might not have even been here to lead the debate on these amendments that the Government is proposing. The Opposition would like to have more bureaucratic controls even though it says it would not. Its attention should have been drawn to something that Lord Keynes said during a BBC broadcast in 1945:

SPEECH.PARA: At last the public exchequer has recognised the support and encouragement of the civilising arts of life as part of their duty.

If the Opposition had thought about that and the role that the Australia Council and other government funded arts organisations have in the life of Australia, it might have put a little more thought into its contribution to this debate. Instead the Opposition spokesman says, `Well, the worst thing that can happen to arts in Australia is that Gough Whitlam be given charge of the Australia Council'. When one looks at the Opposition's approach to arts funding in Australia and one goes back to the many years that the Liberals were in government, prior to Gough Whitlam becoming Prime Minister of Australia, one sees that the arts got relatively nothing out of the Liberal Party. In fact, it was Gough Whitlam who was the great impetus, with Jean Battersby, Nugget Coombs and others, in putting arts on the Federal agenda. But Opposition members know so little about the subject that they think that one of the worst things that could happen would be for Gough Whitlam to have something to do with arranging arts policy in Australia. The Opposition, as usual, has it all wrong. the Opposition is in the same position as Stephen Sondheim was when he put a song in that little confection called Sunday in the Park with George. In that there is a little verse that says:
Art isn't easy even when you're hot.
Advancing art is easy. Financing it is not.

That is the problem that the Opposition has. It wants to be able to say all the things that it would like to say but, when it gets around to doing something about it, it has a real problem. In fact, it puts forward rather contradictory statements. It worries about bureaucratic intervention, Gough Whitlam, this Minister and that Minister. When the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) asked the Opposition what it would do, it said, `You'll have to wait till you see our policy'. An election was held last year and the Opposition did not have a policy then. There will be another election in a couple of years' time, but we have not yet seen a policy from the Opposition. The fact is that it does not have a policy. The people who are running the arts area on behalf of the Opposition are the cultural philistines of the Waste Watch Committee.

The Opposition spokesman-the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith)-told us what a great job the Waste Watch Committee has done in finding out what ought to happen to arts funding in Australia. According to what we have heard from the honourable member for Bass, Senator Michael Baume and the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), the Waste Watch Committee will tell us what is right for art and what is not right for art; what is right for Australians and what is not right for Australians. That is the very reason that the Government has to keep the Australia Council model for arts funding in Australia. If it did not do so, members of the Waste Watch Committee would decide what was culture. I think that they would probably take their definition of culture from Goering because Goering once said: `When I hear someone talk about culture I get out my gun'. That is the view that members of the Waste Watch Committee would have. We need to have someone to put between those cultural philistines and the people who are deciding on what Lord Keynes said was a very noble thing for governments to do.

I went into the inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, of which I was Chairman, thinking that maybe there ought to be some significant changes to the Australia Council. A number of people who appeared before my Committee told me that the Australia Council model ought to be changed. A number of people took the view of the Waste Watch Committee. A number of people took another view, but for finer motives. After talking to hundreds of witnesses and after going through four and a half thousand pages of transcript of evidence, the Committee came down with a unanimous report. The honourable member for Bass did not mention, in his fulminations, that he was a member of that Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was on the subcommittee.

—The honourable member would be aware that even subcommittees have to get their proposals agreed to by the whole committee. The honourable member for Bass voted for the Committee report-but now he seems to have been taken over by the Waste Watch Committee. It is amazing what happens to people when they become ambitious. The honourable member for Bass is now saying to the Parliament that we ought to go and have another look at this.

SPEECH.PARA: I came to the conclusion, as did all members of the Committee, that if we wanted to go away from the arts council model and move to an arts ministry model, the waste watch committees ought to have a field day. If one looks at the way arts funding is done in the States-be they Liberal or Labor States-one sees pork-barrelling of the worst type. In the Commonwealth we have a different approach. In the Commonwealth we have said that we will have a form of peer review and arm's length funding: we will have the experts give us some information-not the dulcet tones of the honourable member for Mayo, the addled approach of the honourable member for Bass or the pernickety, stockbroker approach of Senator Michael Baume. We have said that we will have some people who actually know what they are talking about give us some advice. That is probably a strange concept for the Opposition to accept and why it is in such a parlous state at present. All it is bothering to do is to listen to its own empty echoes. If it went out and got some proper advice, and thought about that advice, it might be able to come in here and tell us that it has an arts policy; it might be able to have something constructive to say about these very good changes that the Government is making to the Australia Council model. There is no doubt that there were some deficiencies in the arts council model of running a large arts industry in Australia in the 1980s.

The Government has not said, as the Opposition would like it to do, `Let's throw the baby out with the bath water and let us dole out all these things to our friends'. The Opposition spokesman had the hide to say that the Australia Council boards are made up of the Minister's friends. It may be that Labor Ministers are a little more cultured and have a wider sphere of friends. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, who is at the table, would count his friends by the hundreds; whereas Senator Puplick and the Opposition spokesman would be hard-pressed to even get invited to the opera, let alone bother to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! That is totally insulting and you know it. I would like that withdrawn.
—The honourable member for Cook can get up here afterwards and try to make some apologies for his colleagues-

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: An aspersion has been cast on Senator Puplick's art appreciation. I would like the honourable member for Grayndler to withdraw it. The claim that Senator Puplick does not go to the opera is a complete falsehood and the honourable member knows it.
—I see no point in asking the honourable member for Grayndler to withdraw.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Cook has just told us that Senator Puplick buys a ticket to the opera from time to time. Well, good on him. Maybe in the future we will see him at a rock and roll concert and then we can talk to him about popular culture. Then we might find out where the Opposition stands on something. What we have seen here today is a scandal. We would have been far better hearing from the honourable member for Cook about where the Opposition thinks arts is going than from that empty drum that stood up and told us that Gough Whitlam knows nothing about art. The honourable member for Cook would not tell us that Gough Whitlam should not have anything to say about art in Australia. The honourable member for Cook probably thinks that having Gough Whitlam with something to do with the arts is a good idea.
—He said he would not take the position of chairman.

—The Opposition spokesman has just found some other things to say which he did not have time to say when he still had 10 minutes in which to speak. He could not even go the full round. That shows how little he knows about the issues. We found that some changes needed to be made to the arts council model and we suggested some changes. An all-party committee-including the honourable member for Bass-said, with the honourable member for Bass, that we ought to make some of these changes. I think that the changes which the Minister has introduced, together with the other changes that the Australia Council has made, will assist the implementation of government art policies in Australia, as well as doing their best to keep the politicians from dictating what art should be. One tends to think that the Opposition gets its thoughts from watching Yes, Minister on the television. If Opposition members watch Yes, Minister, as most of them probably do, they will have heard a great quote from Sir Humphrey Appleby, that doyen of the Civil Service on Yes, Minister, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Subsidy is for art; it's for culture. It's not to be given to what the people want. It is for what the people don't want but ought to want. If they really want something they will pay for it themselves. The Government's duty is to subsidise education, enlightenments and spiritual uplift-not the vulgar pastimes of ordinary people.

If we had the arts ministry model, the Humphrey Applebys of this world would be telling the Minister who to give the grants to. It would not be any of those addle-brained people on the other side who have no idea of what they want to do; it would be the secretary to the arts department. The Government, quite properly, has put a buffer in there-the Australia Council. That buffer provides the Government with advice and an expert selection system. On occasions the Australia Council could have ended up doing what it wanted to do rather than taking account of government policy. It is proper for the Australia Council to take account of government policy, but I believe that it is really improper for Ministers to decide, at the micro-economic level, which grant should be given to which group. Of course, that is what the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee would do. Those cultural philistines would want to go through every grant. They would decide what was and was not important as a function of their own narrow appreciation of things. However, as a result of these proposed amendments, the Australia Council will have to take account of the broad thrust of government policy. I think that is a very good thing.

One of the other things which my Committee found when it went round Australia, unlike the Opposition, was that people had some criticisms of the Australia Council as a model for the delivery of arts funds but could not give a better solution. No-one within the arts industry-no-one out in the community-really liked the idea of a cultural ministry operation at the Commonwealth level. I suppose it gets down to the old saw about democracy, that democracy has all sorts of flaws. Every day we see those flaws in this chamber. Democracy flowers when there is a strong opposition, but one of the great flaws at present is that we do not have a strong opposition. However, even with the flaws in democracy, it is still the very best system available.

It is my belief that the Australia Council model certainly has flaws. From time to time governments should try to overcome some of those flaws. However, the Australia Council seems to be one of the best vehicles available at present for the delivery of arts funding at the Commonwealth level. I think that the Government, particularly the Minister for the Arts and Territories, should be congratulated on making these changes, which will broaden the base of the Australia Council. It has been perceived for quite some time that there needs to be another view, as well as the view of the arts experts. My Committee has suggested, and the Government has accepted, that we should broaden the base of the people participating in that peer review process and that arm's length funding process so that people who have some expertise in public administration or some other field-people other than those who are necessarily arts practitioners-can be brought into the decision-making process. We think that that would broaden the base of the decision-making process and that it would then ensure that some of the criticisms levelled at the Australia Council would not be able to be levelled any more.

One of the points brought up by the honourable member for Bass in his contribution was that we seem to be funding an arts bureaucracy. I think that this is a myth that many people around Australia have pushed for some time. There is no doubt that if the rest of the bureaucracy that delivers large and complex programs could get its administration costs down to the level of the Australia Council, we would be in a very good position with regard to the country's deficit. Administration costs of 12 per cent for running a program are not very high. The Australia Council is a pretty lean administrative organisation. Eighty-eight per cent of the funds appropriated to the Australia Council go to arts recipients. If the honourable member for Bass and his colleague Senator Puplick had a look at similar programs, I think they would find that the administration costs were higher. In all fairness to Senator Puplick, I do not think that that is a criticism that he makes of the Australia Council.

We heard as well some questions raised by the Opposition on the removal of the Design Board. John Andrews, who was a member of the Design Board, has an interest in what it is doing and is strongly putting his point of view. However, with due respect to John Andrews and the Design Board people who share that view, I think they are wrong. If we have a problem with design of the type raised by the honourable member for Bass, who said that there is no centre of excellence in design in Australia, maybe one of the reasons for that problem lies in the fact that the Design Board is located within the Australia Council. I think that design in Australia will end up doing far better if John Andrews and the very good people like him start to exercise their influence in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, because that is where the real money is. That is where the really significant appropriations for excellence in design can be made. Indeed, design has to become enmeshed in Australia's manufacturing industry if manufacturing industry is to blossom and contribute to Australia's economy. Whilst it might suit people from the Design Board to think that the Australia Council is a better home for them, a far more productive home for the Board would be in Senator Button's Department.

I finish by saying that I think that the Government's amendments to the Australia Council Act will benefit both art practitioners and art consumers. By that I mean art and culture in the broadest possible terms. I do not hold to the view and I believe the Government does not hold to the view that art is just that narrow band of high arts. In the last two years the Government has made some significant changes to the way in which it funds broader cultural areas. On the one hand, we are looking at contemporary music and on the other, as the honourable member for Bass would have seen in the Budget, we have developed for the first time ever a small program of, I think, about $1.3m per annum for people of excellence. One of the worst things that was happening was that excellent artists were travelling overseas and staying there. What the Government has done, both the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for the Arts and Territories, in this Budget is to ensure that we encourage those people to stay here. This Government has a commitment to art and culture at both the highest and the broadest levels. These proposed amendments to the Australia Council Act will ensure that that commitment continues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me start by saying that the release of the Opposition's arts policy is not in any way, shape or form going to be dictated by the timing decision of the Government to have its junior Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) introduce this amendment to the Australian Council Act on his second last day as Minister with that portfolio. Unlike the previous speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), I do not intend to become personal about honourable members on either the Government side or the Opposition side. I do not plan to raise the issue of honourable members' latter-day interest in the arts, but just to talk for a few moments on the Australia Council Amendment Bill. The Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts and Territories, and the two members of the Government and two members of the Opposition who are in the chamber at this time to listen to the debate on this subject will know that we are about to release our arts policy within a very short time. Let us then have a rather full-blooded debate on other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the decision of the Opposition to oppose the Bill. I believe that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) has spoken quite adequately about the bureaucratisation of the debate. One of the great problems that happen in the arts-I speak as one who has been interested in the arts both as a practitioner and as an interested person all my life-lies in administering the arts. I am not relating these comments on administration of the arts to either side of the House. One of the basic problems with administering the arts is whether the role of the art administrators is to encourage a wider range of people to become interested and concerned in one form of the arts or artistic endeavour or whether it is to acknowledge, encourage and sponsor the special talents of very talented people. The honourable member for Grayndler quite properly touched on the differences in the roles of Federal and State governments in sponsoring, encouraging and acknowledging the arts. I have no reason to disagree with him on those points.

In this country we are finding a growing interest by the third level of government, local government, in becoming interested in particularly the visual arts, if not the performing arts. I for one, with no criticism levelled at the retiring Minister, welcome the new Minister with great encouragement. As the honourable member for Bass said, he ought to be welcomed. I welcome him wholeheartedly. I am very much aware of the strength of his interest in the visual arts. I believe that he will bring to the portfolio a great talent for understanding the problems facing those who are involved in the visual arts. However, I do not believe that we should get too concerned about who runs the organisations. The real problem is the end result of the Government's policies. Are we going to see artistic form as part of our daily life or are we going to regard any expression of art-or artistic expression, to put it another way-as being something elitist? I believe that this is a false and slightly philistine attitude towards art in daily life.

We are talking of getting models and what model the Australia Council should be. Let me suggest to the Parliament that the Arts Advisory Committee of the new Parliament House is a very useful model for any future administration that may take place in the visual arts. Perhaps the House is not aware that the Arts Advisory Committee, on which I was privileged to sit for six years as a parliamentary representative, brought out new forms of legal contracts. It brought out new forms of tendering for the use of art in public buildings. I would hope that the basis of the work done by the Arts Advisory Committee, under the superb chairmanship of Sir Laurence Muir and consisting of a most talented and wide-ranging group of people concerned with all forms of arts and crafts, is not just put to one side and ignored. Future approaches to administration of visual arts should look very clearly and closely at what that Committee achieved in the six years it was in operation and how it was encouraged by a great firm of international architects to see the art aspect of this building as part of the operation of the building and not just to take some museum-type approach.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler, talked about the differences between opera and rock'n'roll. So be it. If there is dedication to the art form, then it should be encouraged. I believe that those who apply themselves seriously to artistic expression should be serious in their intention if they are to expect government encouragement or acknowledgment, whether at Federal, State or local level.

The chance of finding excellent administrators of the various art forms is very slim; it is very rare. In Australia we have had people such as Charles Berg, who died quite recently. He proved to be a superb man with regard to the promotion and administration of the now world acknowledged Australian Opera company. I believe he ranked in the same area as Rudolph Bing of the New York Metropolitan Opera in his better days. Today I would like to pay tribute also to Max Bourke, the present executive officer of the Australia Council, for the work he is valiantly trying to do to bring some sense into the application of the tasks that face the Australia Council.

I am not going to talk about the waste of money in the arts, as my colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) will be doing that when he follows me in this debate. But there is one point in the Bill which I take exception to, and I would like to talk about it now, despite the amendment that should be coming forward. It concerns the decision to remove the word `film' from the art form. As many of us know, the Literature Board of the Australia Council has great difficulty finding people who can write satisfactory scripts for the Australian film industry. The House should be reminded that, because of the strength of the language and the degree of violence appearing in some Australian films, they basically do not qualify for appearance on Australian television because of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's standards. So there is a great need for the training area of the film industry and the Literature Board to work closer together in the development of appropriate script writers within our film industry. There is a basic and sad lack of script writers in nearly every film industry around the world. One of the tragedies of films is that the wealthy film companies eventually take over all the talented script writers and other facilities. I am most disappointed that by taking `film' out of the description of art we are moving away from a really practical application of work for the current Australia Council.

As I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, I believe that the Bill increases bureaucratic intervention. It is appropriate for the Opposition to pick its time for the release of its arts policy and not be guided, as I said earlier, by the decision of this Government to flatter its retiring Minister for the arts by allowing him to bring this Bill into the House on his second last day as Minister. In his next portfolio-might I say as a kind aside to him-he will be hearing a lot more from me, and I hope to be hearing a lot more from him. But, of course, I am out of the context of this debate by saying so.

I do not believe anything is achieved in this House by name calling, and the Minister will know that. I do not do it locally. We are political neighbours; our electorates adjoin each other. I do not believe in political abuse at any level, even in telephone calls, which may be recorded-a matter which for some reason seems to have crept into this debate today. I hope that the work of Max Bourke and the Australia Council is not in any way challenged or reduced by the introduction of this Bill and no doubt the passing of it in this House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You never know; they might cross.
—One can only hope that the Government will see the light in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Council Amendment Bill 1988 will give effect to the Government's response to the inquiry into Commonwealth assistance to the arts by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, a committee chaired by a Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay). It is a pleasure to be able to follow the honourable member for Grayndler on this side of the chamber in this debate because, if I might be allowed to digress slightly, I think that his Committee's report, which was entitled Patronage, Power and the Muse, is a beacon for other committees of this place in the way in which they can make a significant contribution to formulating government policy.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of debate about how this new building will affect the way in which we operate as members of parliament. I know that there have been criticisms of the size of the building and, therefore, the isolation. There have also been criticisms about the fact that there is a special ministerial wing and that that might isolate Ministers from backbenchers. One outstanding feature of this building is the committee complex, which I think is a wonderful set of rooms. It has all the types of electronic gadgetry which will enable the works of the committees to be known to all. They will be able to be connected both aurally and, in the long term, visually to all rooms. I think it is significant that the committee system which was set up following last year's election will enable back bench members of this House and the other place to play a role in the formulation of policy and the review of government administration. As I said, this committee report, which was the genesis of a lot of the work that has been completed by this Bill, is significant in that regard, because it shows the extent to which the workings of committees of the Parliament can succeed.

This Bill acts upon the recommendations of the McLeay report calling for a more streamlined administrative structure for the Australia Council, a structure responsive to government policies. The amendments to the Australia Council Act 1975 contained in this Bill are intended to ensure a more efficient arts council organisation and to clarify the relationship between the Australia Council and the Government. Striking the correct balance in this relationship is a complex issue, as has been outlined in some of the contributions in this debate. On the one hand, the overt political control of the arts has been one of the hallmarks of totalitarianism. Nevertheless, democratic institutions have not been a guarantee against the accusation that arts funding has been used as a means of influencing political and social development or as a courtly hobby of Ministers. In 1972 Dr Jean Battersby, Executive Officer of the then Australian Arts Council, pointed out:

The tendency to see the arts as an instrument of ideological and social conditioning is not confined to the communist countries. Even in France where the ministry was, under General de Gaulle, headed by Andre Malraux, an artist of great power as well as an understanding scholar in the history of the arts, there developed serious criticism of the political use of his powers and an alienation of the most vigorous and creative art's from the ministry.

The most common model that has been developed to counter this problem is the Arts Council, incorporating an arm's length relationship with government and a peer review involvement of artists and those associated with the arts in decision making. The advantages of this model, as outlined before the McLeay Committee by the Australia Council, are: statutory independence, which is seen as fundamental in upholding freedom of artistic expression and ensuring that government funds are not restricted to politically acceptable art; capacity to support innovatory, experimental projects which could be political liabilities if supported directly by government; and an advocacy and policy development role on behalf of the arts community that is free from short term political considerations.

The Arts Council model and the Australia Council are not without their critics. It might be argued that the concepts of arms length funding and peer review are ill-defined; that the Australia Council is at least, in part, the captive of its clients; that it has been a vehicle by which cultural policy has been determined by artists and their colleagues; and that this in turn has led to the imposition of policy on the community by a select elite group.

While Gough Whitlam has rightly argued that `in any civilised community the arts and associated amenities must occupy a central place and their enjoyment should not be seen as something remote from everyday life', it is undeniable that in Australia subsidised arts and, in particular, the so-called high arts are principally occidental in focus and are removed from and not enjoyed by the vast majority of ordinary Australians.

A national conference on arts policy for a multicultural Australia held in March this year and sponsored by the Australia Council, the Office of Multicultural Affairs of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the South Australian Bannon Government's Department of the Arts was highly critical of the very low level of support available to artists of non-Anglo Celtic backgrounds. A report of the conference in a recent edition of Artforce, the Australia Council's newsletter, pointed out:

The message from the speakers was clear-that the cultural diversity resulting from Australia's immigration programs should be more fully exploited in the development of cultural programs. And further, that those responsible for developing these programs must see it as their responsibility to assist and promote a full range of artists in the community.

In no area other than the arts can the differences between a policy of multiculturalism and the notion of one Australia be seen to be so different. In Australia, where we are continuing to develop our identity, it is obvious, given the background and the contribution that migrants have made, that Australia will continue to be a multicultural society and will be importantly enhanced not only economically by the contribution of migrants but also in cultural terms by their involvement.

Between them, the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust, the Australian Opera and the Australian Ballet absorb approximately 26 per cent of Australia Council funds. Large State theatre and dance companies absorb a further 8 per cent to 10 per cent. There are some in the community who view this level of funding with concern. As Graham Seal of the Australian Folk Trust argued before the McLeay Committee:

Opera and ballet are hardly the cultural treasures of Australia. They are the cultural treasures of the old world, transplanted and cosseted at the taxpayers expense into an overstuffed antique with meagre relevance to the Australian experience.

I do not wish to suggest that the areas of activity currently funded by the Australia Council are unworthy of continued support. However, taking into account Graham Seal's extreme view, the point should be made that, in an electorate such as Scullin, very few people will ever see a performance of one of the so-called flagships. As the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) reflected, it seems that, like all good satire, the Sir Humphrey Appleby view that subsidy is to be given not to what people want but for what people do not want but ought to have is a distortion of reality but not entirely untrue. The McLeay Committee rightly rejected the view that it is the role of Government subsidy to simply provide wider access to traditional European high arts. The Committee took an approach to democratising the arts, as outlined in its first recommendation:
Commonwealth arts support policy should aim to democratise culture by ensuring wide and ready community access to a diversity of cultural experiences.

Arts policy should build on the work of individuals like the late George Seelaf. George Seelaf made a tremendous contribution to the Australian trade union movement. For 26 years he was the Victorian Secretary of the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union. He was a pioneer in Union involvement in occupational health and safety, playing a major role in the creation of the trade union medical clinic in the Melbourne western suburb of Footscray, a clinic which was a model for many community health centres in other disadvantaged areas, but also importantly specialised in industrial medicine and occupational health and safety.

George Seelaf also had a passionate vision of making arts and culture accessible to working people. As a union official, he organised lunchtime recitals and the like in the workplace. In 1973, after his retirement from the meat workers union, George Seelaf took a part time position as the Victorian Trades Hall Council's first arts officer. He was involved in the Footscray and Victorian 150th anniversary committees and in the establishment of the Footscray Symphony Orchestra. He sat on the Myer committee of inquiry into public funding of the arts. Earlier this year, prior to his recent death, a George Seelaf trust fund was established to further his work by providing grants for workplace and community art in Melbourne's western suburbs. The challenge for government is to implement George Seelaf's vision of artistic and cultural life that is accessible and meaningful to all Australians.

An important step in fostering the further democratisation of the arts is striking a correct balance in the relationship between the Australia Council and the Government. The amendments in the Bill before the House do not infringe on the Australia Council's independence regarding grant decisions; they do, however, provide mechanisms for the Minister to communicate to the Council in writing on any matter and to direct the Council in its activities. This is in keeping with the Government's actions to incorporate a general power of ministerial direction in relation to statutory bodies.

The amendments also provide for the Council to have regard to the policies of State and local governments as they relate to the arts. In passing, I noted the comments of the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) when he outlined and indicated his awareness of the growing involvement of local government in the arts. This is to be encouraged because local government, as is often said, is the closest form of government to the people and therefore is perhaps in the best position to cater to the community's interests in all areas, including the arts. The amendments allow membership of the Council and its boards to representatives of community interest. This is particularly important as it will broaden the focus of the Australia Council to better reflect the concerns of the consumers of arts programs and the public at large.

A related change which reflects both the Government's desire for a more efficient administrative structure and greater community input into the Council is the establishment of a new coordinating board. This board will have a large, flexible membership, including representation from the general public. The new provisions allow the Minister to establish this board as a community cultural development board. This measure is in line with the Government's response to the McLeay report. A community cultural development board should set about enhancing access to the arts at the community level. The importance of successfully filling this role can not be over-stressed.

Democratisation of the subsidised arts is ultimately the only guarantee of their long term survival. For if it is true, as is sometimes alleged, that the majority of Australians pay for their entertainment directly out of their own pockets and subsidise the entertainment of a small minority of others through their taxes, then it is a situation which cannot go on for ever. The Minister for Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) has said that the amendments in this Bill, together with reforms already undertaken by the Australia Council itself in response to government policy and the McLeay report, will provide the Australia Council with a more responsive structure into the next decade. This is the only way forward. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The English writer John Elsom was famous not for many things but for his quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The word `art' is like God: you may believe that it exists, but as soon as you try to define it, then bigotry creeps in.

Much of the debate we have had in Australia over government involvement in the arts, both at Federal and State level, has involved a great deal of bigotry. I suppose in a general sense one would say that too many debates in this country really amount to little more than an exchange of slogans, rather than a proper analysis of the issues involved. Nowhere has that been truer than in the debate about government involvement in the arts. There is a strongly held view that the status quo should never be challenged. Any challenge to that status quo has been regarded as utterly outrageous-rather like talking about sex in the Victorian era. As a nation, we really need to think much more carefully and debate in a much more mature way the whole issue of government involvement in the arts.

The first point that I think all honourable members of this House should make, if they are interested in the arts, is that in Australia there is an enormous enthusiasm for the arts. There is a view, at least among foreigners, that Australia is not one of the great cultural centres of the world. That is completely false. We should explain to people that it is false; there is enormous enthusiasm for the arts, not just because `arts is entertainment'-to use the expression of the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), the former Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment-but because of the very important cultural contribution which the arts make to the lives of Australians. I suppose that it is no exaggeration to say that through the arts of this country we, in some respects, define our existence; we criticise the way our society works; we celebrate some of the things that we like about our society, our country and its environment and way of life. It is also often said that it is the way in which we build our country, advance its cultural and intellectual character and build the sort of Australia that will evolve over the next generations.

Let us make no mistake: Australians' love for the arts can be easily quantified-as everything can these days-in an economic sense. It is a multi-billion dollar industry which creates something like 120,000 jobs. So there is no question that the arts is important in an economic sense, as well as being fundamentally important in a cultural sense.

The Australia Council Amendment Bill is a manifestation of the so-called McLeay report, entitled `Patronage, Power and the Muse', and to be brutally honest I must say that I do not think that report is a shining light, as the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) described it, in the debate on the arts. When I first read it I thought it was profoundly disappointing. I would have hoped that the Parliament could have produced a much better report on the arts. I think that one of the best reports produced on the arts in Australia in the past 20 years was the 1986 Industries Assistance Commission report on the arts. While there were some things about that report that I really did not like, I do think that it was a tremendously good reference document and the McLeay report is a popgun compared with that big piece of ammunition. The changes that the Opposition is opposing are relatively minor. What they do not do is redress the enormous mess in which the Federal Government's arts policy has gradually found itself.

Before I talk about that, let me agree with what the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) and others said in congratulating the work of Max Bourke, who has tried to inject some common sense and sanity into the Australia Council. At times I think that common sense has not really been the hallmark of that organisation. Many people in the arts community argue that the way the Australia Council administers grants and the way in which the Federal Government's arts policy is now constructed is an example-perhaps this is an overstatement-of Labor's cronyism. The Minister is able to appoint people to the Australia Council. So much for the so-called principle of `arms length funding' with no ministerial involvement. Of course there is when the Minister appoints appropriate people, as he or she would see it, to the Australia Council. Of course the Chairman of the Australia Council, Donald Horne, is a man who pursues quite openly and very blatantly a political agenda. He uses the Australia Council as much as he uses any other forum to pursue what he believes to be the appropriate political agenda.

There is also widespread criticism, to which the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) referred, about the way that grants from the Australia Council are allocated. Some people in the arts community have complained to me that there is a sort of network of mates who distribute grants to each other. They claim that that network of mates is particularly dominant in the city of Sydney, where the Minister comes from, but that people from other parts of Australia have no access whatsoever to those grants. That again may be an overstatement, but it seems to me that there is some foundation of truth in it. These are very common statements that one hears throughout the arts community.

The Waste Watch Committee has been referred to and I will return to the allegation that it was filled up with a lot of philistines. That, coming from some honourable members opposite, I think is rather risible, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I am sure you would be the first to agree. But the Waste Watch Committee did this country a very real service by drawing the attention of Australians to the way in which some of their money was being used to fund a lot of arts projects which had more political than artistic value.

If we run through the 1986-87 annual report of the Australia Council we can see that this is still going on. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, which I do not think anyone would argue was set up as an arts organisation, received $26,750 in grants. The Western Australian Trades and Labour Council received $16,000 in arts grants. The United South Australian Trades and Labour Council-from my own State-received a massive $50,000 worth of arts grants. Yet the Arts Council of South Australia, which is the predominant community arts body in that State, received only $78,500. I repeat that there was $50,000 to the Trades and Labour Council in South Australia for arts grants.

There are bodies like the Workers Cultural Action Committee, which got nearly $28,000 worth of grants. Trade union arts officers have received $42,000 in grants. I have always made the point that I have no objection to trade unions being involved in the arts. I am happy to see them being involved. I have no objection to big business, or small business for that matter, being involved in the arts. But I think there is a limit to where we distribute taxpayers' funds through the Federal Government and the Australia Council, and I think giving arts grants to trade unions really does go beyond that limit. Some of the grants have really been absurd. The Food Preservers Union got a grant for ceramics classes. The Australian Metal Workers Union got a grant for a painting-a very good painting those who have seen it have told me; I am not detracting from its quality-which hangs in the AMWU offices in Sydney. Taxpayers pay for the grant so that the painting can be produced, but the taxpayers are not able to see where their money has gone. I think that is basically wrong; I really do.

But beyond criticising just the details of some of these grants-and, of course, that will always be a subject of some contention-I think a lot of the philosophy of the Government's arts policy is fundamentally wrong. the Government, it was revealed during the last Federal election campaign-which was particularly interesting in terms of the way the Australian Labor Party perceived the arts-apparently despises the emphasis we on this side of the House place on excellence and achievement in the arts. We have Labor member after Labor member and trade unionist after trade unionist sneering at our argument that we should be concentrating taxpayers' money on excellence and achievement. They said we were being elitist. Well, if elitism means doing things well, I would have thought that that was not a particularly pejorative expression. If they want to call us elitist, so be it, because our emphasis where taxpayers' money is concerned is indeed on doing things well, rather than concentrating taxpayers' money in the arts on a lot of middle class mendicant mates of some parts of the Australian Council.

Let me go further with the Australia Council, because I have been sitting around waiting to get my own back a bit here. Professor Horne, as the Chairman of the Australia Council, has, I think, pursued a very blatant political agenda, and in doing that has brought discredit on himself-not from the people on the other side of the House, who regard him as a sort of sage and a hero, but from many people throughout the community. As Professor Horne pointed out in his Chairman's introduction to the latest annual report of the Australia Council, he regards Australian cultural life as derivative. That is a pretty pejorative thing to say about Australia-to say that this country is just derivative. Obviously there are aspects of it which are derivative, but Australia over 200 years-and perhaps one should include as well the 40,000 years of Aboriginal culture-has developed its own cultural identity, an identity of which we should be proud. We should not go around saying we are derivative. But Professor Horne thinks too much in Australia is what he describes as `derivative'. We all know his views on things like the monarchy--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Stockmen's Hall of Fame. He attacked that the other night.

—Actually, I am not sure of his views of the Stockmen's Hall of Fame. But he thinks the flag and many of the traditions of Australia are complete and utter rubbish, and I suppose that is what he means by `derivative'. He points this out in his annual report; that we have to do more to get away from something he describes as `derivative'. I think that is an expression, at least intellectually, of his sort of agenda. In his annual report he goes on to say a whole range of things which I think, frankly, are rather regrettable, coming from somebody who is supposed to be the independent head of a statutory authority. But Professor Horne's philosophy is the philosophy, if you like, of the nanny state: the Australia Council knows best. There is an absolutely staggering presumption in what he says that if anybody outside the Australia Council dare criticise the grants, even though those grants are made with other people's money, that person is somehow a philistine and anti-intellectual.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) said that the Waste Watch Committee was made up of philistines. I think that comment is particularly inappropriate. One can say what one likes about the Waste Watch Committee, but it certainly was not composed of people who, in terms of the arts, were philistines. Many of them were tremendously enthusiastic supporters of the arts. But the Waste Watch Committee criticised grants made by the Australia Council, and people like Professor Horne and his friends in the Labor Party regard this as utterly outrageous. Let us look at what Professor Horne says in his annual report:
The most disappointing-
fair enough, he can think it is disappointing, but he says also-
debilitating and dangerous type of criticism made of the Australia Council during the year was connected with attacks on grant processes including those of the Australia Council . . .

Professor Horne's arrogance, his intellectual snobbery, his total contempt for democratic processes where ordinary people's money is being spent by Professor Horne and the Australia Council, and his contempt for members of parliament expressing values and views about the way that money is spent are really staggering. It is the most undemocratic sort of arrogance imaginable. It is the sort of attitude and arrogance that was so characteristic of the last days of the Bourbon regime in France of Louis XVI and Marie-Antoinette-perhaps one could go back further to include Louis XIV and Louis XV as well. It is the sort of attitude that says, `What would the people know? What would they know about the great arts? What would they know about the way their money should be spent? We should not involve them in those sorts of processes. They are just philistines; they are just fools. The people shouldn't be involved. We will take their money from them, but don't let them tell us how we should spend it. We know better than they do'. I would have thought that the Labor Party, which professes to be so enthusiastic about democratic principles, would find that attitude pretty offensive-apparently not. Apparently when it comes to the arts everything is different. All the traditions of parliamentary democracy are fine in relation to most areas of human activity, but the arts is completely different.

Professor Horne is more than just somebody who is intellectually arrogant about ordinary people. He is somebody who, during the last election campaign, revealed himself as being a completely party political figure, and I think that was a very inappropriate and improper thing for a head of a government authority to do. I have here an article from the Australian of 8 June 1987, in which Professor Horne decided that he would go public and attack the Opposition's approach to the arts. Many of the things he said about the stand the Opposition took were just totally false. They were doubtless helpful to the Labor Party. He said that under the Opposition's policy the arts would `become a political matter'. That is a staggering thing to say. He is a political matter, saying things like that during an election campaign. And he accuses the Opposition of wanting to politicise the arts. We have no intention at all of politicising the arts or arts grants. Yet he did not speak to me, as the then shadow Minister, about this question; he simply went to the media and accused us of politicising the arts. Another quote from the same article has Professor Horne saying:

Mr Downer's statement that `there need to be significant changes if, as a community, we are to get better value for money for our arts dollars and ensure that arts funding bears some relationship to community tolerance and aspirations', was an attempt to place restrictions on the freedom of the arts.

That is what I mean by the sort of intellectual arrogance and contempt for democratic processes that we on this side of the House have had to put up with in the arts debate for far too long. The article goes on:
Professor Horne said there would have been no modern painting and no modern sculpture if such a yardstick had been used in the past.

Who would believe that sort of party political rhetoric on behalf of the Labor Party? That is just a disgraceful thing to say during an election campaign. We said things that I know he agreed with, but when, for example, we talked about the New South Wales Government making a greater contribution to the funding of the Australian Opera Professor Horne refused to comment. He is quite happy to go around giving us a good hammering in the media and at some public forum to which he did not invite the Opposition; he is quite happy to go around being a party political figure for the Labor Party; but when it comes to talking about the aspects of the Opposition's policy that he agrees with, he does not really care and he will not comment.

The fact is that significant changes need to be made in funding for the arts and in the way that the arts will develop in this country. We need to restructure the Australia Council significantly so that there is significantly less emphasis on spending money on arts administrators and on administration in general, to ensure that the money that this Parliament votes for the arts goes to the artists. The Government boasts that it has reduced the administrative bill for the Australia Council-and I congratulate Max Bourke on what he has achieved there-but it was still $6.7m last year, out of a $43m total budget for the Australia Council. I do not accept the Government's argument that it could never reduce that. Indeed, as I argued during the last election campaign, if the Australia Council was set up as an advisory body rather than an administrative body, we would be able to ensure that the bulk of that $6.7m went to the people who needed it, the creative people of Australia, not arts bureaucrats. I have made the point again and again that I think the Australia Council needs to be properly accountable to this Parliament, as is arts funding in the States of New South Wales, South Australia, Victoria-and so the list goes on.

There is no controversy at all on the other side of the House about arts funding being subject not to ministerial involvement or control but at least to ministerial accountability in each State. There is no debate about that at all but, when it comes to Canberra, apparently all the rules are changed and there is this sort of phoney argument about arms length funding, as though, as I have said a couple of times already, the poor old people just do not matter.

The second change that needs to be made is that we have got to do a lot more to encourage private sector funding. I am sure that the Government would strongly agree on this point. Only 13 per cent of major companies in Australia sponsor the arts now and we must consider more creative and imaginative ways of getting them to do more. I am sure that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) has been thinking of how to do that and I hope that his successor will also do so. We have to ensure that the companies of national significance are properly funded, to ensure that they continue to be companies of national and world significance.

Finally, matters pertaining to community arts must be passed to the community. The funding must come from the States and local government, with the Federal Government funding perhaps only the community arts boards, such as the South Australian community arts boards, but not project grants. The Federal Government has had its fingers very badly burnt in funding project grants, as it has in the funding of the art in working life projects. Let us get the Commonwealth out of all of that and ensure that particularly our museums, our galleries and our companies of national significance are properly funded so that they can do the job they were established to do. Finally, a word about arts education-

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Because this is the last piece of legislation that I will bring to the House in my capacity as Minister for the Arts and Territories, at the outset let me say how much I have enjoyed my limited time in this portfolio. I have found it highly invigorating and I, for one, am not ashamed to stand in this House and say that I believe that I have learnt a great deal by it. I feel broadened as an individual, not only by what I have seen and learnt but also by the people I have met, a number of whom I hope will remain friends down the years.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that that characterises the difference between the Government and the Opposition in relation to this matter. Not one Government speaker has got up today and proclaimed himself to be an expert in the arts-as though if one is not it is some cultural debilitation with which one is born. That is why we on this side of the House believe so passionately in what we have been doing over the past five years in the arts and in what the Australia Council has done.

The Australia Council has been at the forefront of innovation and the encouragement of excellence right across the Australian community, through greater access to the arts, so that the kids from Fairfield in Sydney have as much opportunity and, indeed, as much right to access to the arts, whether it be painting, music, sculpture, acting, or any of the other many sectors of the arts, as have children born of wealthy families. That is what we are about and that is what the Australia Council has been about for quite some time. It is why I will always passionately defend the Australia Council. It has done very great things in this area.

In response to the snide comments that have come across the chamber, some direct and some indirect, might I say that, as kids, neither the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) nor I had the opportunity to learn music or take painting classes. We did not come from backgrounds as privileged as that of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). We did not have the opportunities that he had. But both of us-as indeed is every member on this side of the House-are committed to ensuring that our kids and our grandchildren, and the kids of every working family in this country, have these opportunities, as we develop these programs down the years. That is what this is all about.

This has been a very sad debate in very sad times for Australian politics. In the past week or so we have seen the end of bipartisanship on immigration and ethnic affairs. At the beginning of last week we saw the end of any hope of bipartisanship on Aboriginal affairs. I fear that what we have seen today is the beginning of the end of any semblance of bipartisanship in relation to the arts. This double standard, this about-face, this turnaround, is epitomised by what has happened today.

The recommendations that we are discussing in the House today came from the McLeay report of September 1986. That was a bipartisan and unanimously supported report of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee. For the information of members of the House and for the public more generally, particularly the arts community, I point out that eight Opposition members were party to that report, one of whom was the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who today led the debate against these changes. In not quite two years we have seen a total and complete about-face. As with the debates on immigration and ethnic affairs and Aboriginal Affairs, we now see an attempt to put the New Right dogma in place in the arts and cultural affairs in this country, an attempt to discard all the words and all the work over two years in the compilation of this report as though they did not happen. It is pathetic.

This morning we have heard personal attacks on the Chairman of the Australia Council, Donald Horne. He is more than big enough to defend himself. I found him to be a complete and magnificent chairman of that body. But in attacking the Australia Council for allegedly seing itself as the one and only judge of artistic merit in this country, the Opposition, although it does not realise it, has indicted itself. By scrapping, watering down, appending or siphoning off-whatever the final wording of this policy will be, if it ever comes from the Liberals-members opposite are arrogantly proposing to replace the collective expertise of what is now five boards, which have rotating membership, with peer assessment and the best minds and contributors to the arts in this country, with just one Minister, who will dictate his or her personal opinions, flavours and discretions in the arts according to party dogma. That is a sad thing. If there is one thing that this Government stands for, it is equality of opportunity and the pursuit of excellence in tandem. This country must pursue excellence in science, technology, industry and the arts. We are living in the most exciting of times for the arts in this country. The arts reflect how we are growing and how we are changing-they are leading the way in many respects. The arts stand to gain so much from the tourism boom in this country and tourism stands to gain so much from our artistic and cultural ventures. I believe that the arts must play a greater role in opening doors in foreign affairs and trade for this country.

I agree with the honourable member for Mayo in one respect, and that is that we must see greater private sector involvement in the arts for the mutual benefit of both. But in order to do these things, the arts need to be strong, vibrant and flowing. They need, as it were, to be market determinant of themselves. It is hypocritical in the extreme that we have seen here today that the supposed party of the market denies the arts community the market determinant factor. In terms of the arts debate, the Liberals, like so much that we see now, seek total and absolute control of the sector. What they are suggesting here would reduce the nation's cultural vibrancy to the petty ante of the pork barrel. I suppose that under some future coalition government we would even have someone from the National Party of Australia as the Minister-the ultimate pork barrelling process. We have seen the honourable member for Bass seek to thwart the structure of the Australia Council that encourages the innovative at a time when this country needs to be applauding innovation. We have heard a number of speakers from the other side effectively seek to deny the Chairman, Donald Horne, the right of free speech.

This leads us to the question of the whereabouts of the Liberal Party's arts policy. Senator Puplick, the shadow Minister, instead of swanning around like a drake on the lake and gladhanding at various arts functions, ought to be doing a bit of work and getting the arts policy of the tories in place so at least they can say that they stand for something, because they presently do not. We have only to measure the contributions in this House this morning to see that. The honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), who is a bit more sympathetic to the arts than I think are some of the other members of the Opposition who spoke, said that he hoped the work of Max Bourke was not challenged or reduced by anything in this package. The honourable member for Bass and the honourable member for Mayo tried to do in the Australia Council at 100 miles an hour-their statements were completely in conflict. The honourable member for Cook was praiseworthy about the extent to which local government is now getting involved in the arts. He is going to oppose the Government's package this morning, although proposed new sections 6a and 6b specifically refer to the Australia Council taking cognisance of local government policy in the arts, where local government has been involved in specific areas and specific grants. Indeed, when the honourable member for Mayo said that too often the arts debate in this country has been about an exchange of slogans, how little did he know that he was indicting himself and his colleagues. It is no wonder we have seen no release of the Opposition's arts policy.

If the Opposition gets its way-as I depart this Ministry I sound this warning to the arts community across the country-there will be a very real danger to the cultural and democratic foundations of this country. By the use of ministerial discretion in respect of the supposed flagrantly wrong misnomers about taxpayers' money being wisely spent, we will have a return to the late 1950s when the recipients of arts grants in this country were vetted by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. What a sad state of affairs that would be. Someone should talk to Frank Hardy about the late 1950s. Someone should talk to Judah Waten, the author of Alien Son, to Alan Marshall of I Can Jump Puddles fame and to D'Arcy Niland the author of the Shiralee. They were the sorts of people in the late 1950s who were discriminated against by the Commonwealth literary board which used political discretion in the handing out of arts funding.

Indeed, much of what the Opposition says it is concerned about in this debate this morning is addressed in this package. The Government is streamlining the Australia Council. It is reducing the number of boards from eight to five. Senior Executive Service positions have been reduced from 13 to eight. We have cut over $1m in two years from the administration side of the budget. Only 12 per cent of the Australia Council's budget is now taken up with administrative costs. Earlier this year I gained the agreement of the Australia Council for multi-year funding to encourage further economies of scale. This package is about encouraging access. That is why we are instituting the coordinating board. We are putting community interest representatives on the Council and each of its boards to encourage that access. That is why we are also preserving arm's length funding. I draw the attention of the Opposition to the increased role under proposed new sections 6a and 6b for ministerial directive on policy and program issues. This deliberate intent by the Government was derived directly from the McLeay report recommendations to bring about greater cognisance of policy and program development in accordance with the democratic will of the Parliament and the Government.

We have made those changes. But we have not made the changes that those on the other side of the House have called for, where every grant, every author, every painter, every sculptor, every dancer and every performer would be subject to the political discretion of the government of the day and one single Minister's own dogma, and nor should they. That would be the end of innovation in this country; that would be the end of excellence in the arts. I say to the Opposition here and now: It is wrong. The arts community says it is wrong. As my colleague the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) said to the Opposition on the other topic debated last week, I say that it should retract because it is the wrong. It should retract now.

The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) more than adequately covered the Design Board. I would point out that the sweeping statement that there is no centre for design in this country is quite wrong. We do have the Industrial Design Council of Australia and the Design Institute of Australia.

The amendment circulated by the Opposition seeks to reinsert the term `film' in the preamble to the Australia Council Act. For the purposes of this Act the definitions of the arts relate to the boards that are in the new Australia Council structure. The omission of the word `film' from the Act is purely a housekeeping exercise for the purposes of the Australia Council only. The council originally had a film, television and radio board and this was abolished in 1976, its functions being transferred to the Australian Film Commission. Today the Government has four film organisations: the Australian Film Commission; the Australian Film Television and Radio School-the training arm; the Australian Film Finance Corporation, which we have just set up; and, of course, Film Australia, our own film company. In addition, we have a very heavy involvement in the Australian Children's Television Foundation.

What needs to be said is that the Australian film and television industry this year enjoys $101.385m. The film industry, that arm of the arts covered by film, is more than adequately covered by five arms of government elsewhere, and that is why this exercise is being undertaken. It should be pointed out that the Australia Council has continued to support the film industry through increasing support for Australian writers such as Albert Facey, who wrote A Fortunate Life; Peter Carey who wrote Bliss; Christopher Koch, who wrote The Year of Living Dangerously; and, of course, David Williamson who wrote Emerald City. So that amendment is not necessary. The Opposition should not fear that the film industry is being downgraded in terms of the arts. In fact, the whole action of this Government has been to upgrade its involvement in and support for the film industry. Indeed, that is obviously the case and it is obviously supported by the film industry. The Government has put forward an amendment which will allow teleconferencing for the Australia Council. I am pleased to see that that amendment has the support of the Opposition. The provision of teleconferencing will-the honourable member for Mayo should take account of this-in the long run affect administration costs because it will save a lot of money in air fares.

I conclude by saying that in the last seven months I have enjoyed the arts portfolio, I suppose for one reason in particular, amongst so many, because it symbolises the excellence, creativity and innovation of this country-what it can do, what it can be acclaimed to be doing and what it has done-right around the world. The Sydney Dance Company and the Australian Ballet, through their European performances, have had great reviews and have brought great merit upon this country's good name right around the world. But in every instance of the arts there has to be a starting place, a laboratory of experimentation, a place of innovation. That is, as we on this side of the House acknowledge, subject to policy and program framework laid down by the democratically elected government. These amendments ensure that the Australia Council will, as always, be subject to those policy constraints and, for that matter, those policy performance targets. These amendments allow that innovation and experimentation, where necessary and desirable, to progress and to enhance by allowing the very people who know best about the arts in this country-the arts community itself-to play a great role. It has stood us in great stead for so long and it will continue to do so. For the welfare of this country, its arts and its cultural future, I urge the Opposition to retract from its position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to my questions yesterday regarding the need for constitutional recognition of local government, I now direct a question to the Attorney-General. Can the Attorney-General advise the House of the nature and extent of the longstanding support for constitutional recognition of local government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been well known for some time, local government has always been encouraged to participate in constitutional debates, which have gone on for a long time, some 15 years or more. When the Constitutional Commission invited evidence as to what might be the merits or otherwise of giving some recognition to local government in the Constitution, it received pretty substantial evidence. At present in Australia there are 836 local government authorities, and they do a very worthwhile job. There are 8,000 elected representatives.

ANSWER.PARA: Recognition of local government will be on the basis that there will be a continuance of the system of local government. In no way is it suggested that some system will be designed by the Federal Government or related to Canberra. The proposed constitutional change would give the electors in the community the right to have a local government system. It would also recognise, of course, that State governments can remove local government authorities or amalgamate them. In future communities might not have to be beholden to a local government Minister who may have no real interest in their area. In fact, he may act in a way that causes damage to the area. For example, in Cairns Mr Russ Hinze encouraged development that was against the interests of the community. When the community won a battle in the courts the Queensland Government altered the law to guarantee that the development would take place. Under the proposal also local government bodies would not be beholden to a public servant appointed to administer affairs for their community.

Local government has been in existence since about 1841. It is recognised as a third tier of government. It is a valid form of government. It is proposed to recognise its status in the community so that each community can have an election to replace a local government that may be removed. Communities will not be beholden to local government Ministers. Such Ministers may still continue to sack local government, but the community will be able to get back to the Minister and say, `We want another election'.

Honourable members opposite can make all the mouthings they like, but this country will continue to make that adverse judgment about them because the Australian people are correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question concerns an Australian achievement for the advancement of science. I ask the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business: What is the significance of the Australia Telescope which will be commissioned by the Prime Minister in Culgoora on Friday? Will it restore Australia's pre-eminence in radio astronomy and what are its industrial spin-offs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The commissioning of the Australia Telescope by the Prime Minister on Friday will be the scientific high point of the bicentennial year. It has been one of the greatest projects in the history of astronomy and Australia clearly regains its pre-eminence in radio astronomy. The project has enjoyed strong bipartisan support-like the building of the new Parliament House but at one-twentieth of the cost and with prospects of higher efficiencies and even greater international recognition. It was strongly supported by Malcolm Fraser and David Thomson, as it has been backed by this Government. The most determined opponent of the project has been the former Treasurer, the Leader of the Opposition, who fought it in Cabinet. He does not look pleased.
—Why should he be pleased?

—Exactly. I was pleased to see the supplement on the Australia Telescope in today's Age. It will also appear in tomorrow's Sydney Morning Herald. The Australia Telescope will operate in a `long baseline array' in conjunction with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's 64-metre dish at Parkes. The Prime Minister will commission six antennae, each of 22 metres diameter, on a three-kilometre rail track at Culgoora near Narrabri in the electorate of the honourable member for Gwydir and one more three kilometres away near Mopra near Coonabarabran.
—Why three kilometres away?
—Because it gives perspective for the compact array.
—I thought that was the reason!

—This area in the central-west of New South Wales is close to the optical telescopes at Siding Spring-the Anglo-Australian telescope and the Schmidt telescope. But unlike the Australia Telescope, these two have to work in hours of darkness-rather like the Opposition. The Australia Telescope-and this will gladden the hearts of students of cost-benefit analysis-can work 24 hours a day. It does not matter whether it is raining or cloudy, whether it is night or day. We will get a 24-hour pay back out of the Australia Telescope. In conjunction with the other antennae, here, overseas and in orbit, this telescope will have a resolving power which is 10,000 times greater than the best optical telescopes on earth. The project is a great tribute to Australian industry, which has developed skills in microengineering on a grand scale-if that does not sound too Irish. We have excellent prospects for selling antennae as the spin-off from the Australia Telescope. It is a project in which Government initiatives came first and industry collaboration followed. Had we waited for industry to initiate it, it would never have happened.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that one of the great achievements that we have in microelectronics is the development of something called the correlator chip. Four thousand of these chips are used in the heart of the telescope instrumentation. Each performs 1,000 million multiplications per second-that is faster than the Treasurer--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fractionally.

—Yes, fractionally. This allows the signals from the various antennae to be combined to simulate an antenna six kilometres in diameter. This project is something which we ought to be very proud of collectively and, on behalf of all honourable members, I congratulate all those in the CSIRO who brought this great project to fruition.
