TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the ruling be dissented from.

The nature of the responsibility of government in this place is that the Prime Minister, having been called to Government House, has, above all, a responsibility to nominate those who shall with him exercise the responsibility of government. There is no other member within the ambit of government who can be seen to have responsibility for the actions and deeds of each of those whom he appoints to the respective ministries. Your ruling, Madam Speaker, has said that nobody in the Government has a portfolio responsibility for the behaviour of Ministers. There is no more abject nonsense than for a Prime Minister not to be given a responsibility for those whom he appoints.

The whole concept of our ministerial system is that the person who is Prime Minister is Prime Minister because he has the ability to appoint a ministry, determine the number of Ministers, choose those who will be in Cabinet and set out the responsibilities that they share. Indeed, Madam Speaker, at the beginning of each session you accept the Prime Minister's ability to stand up in this House and make explanations as to who will or will not give answers because some Ministers are not here.

Madam Speaker, your ruling shows absolute contempt for what we see as the exercise of ministerial responsibility. Not only that, Madam Speaker, as we see it, you are determined to deny us on this side of the House a proper opportunity to question Ministers, including the Prime Minister, on those matters that are properly within their care. You are smiling, Madam Speaker; it ill becomes you that you do so. I believe that there is nothing more important than your allowing the Prime Minister to accept total responsibility for those whom he appoints to his Ministry. You in your position are not there to act on behalf of the Government. You are not there to exercise a ruling because any member of the Government asserts that he does not really want to respond. Your responsibility is to this House. The ruling you have just given about responsibility denies you the ability to ask Ministers to answer in accordance with the Standing and Sessional Orders you are called upon to administer and to see that all members observe.

Within our Standing Orders and within our ministerial system, one person alone is responsible for determining Ministers, the duties of Ministers, the allocation of portfolios and the way in which they behave in this House-as my colleague has just said, establishing standards of propriety. Madam Speaker, if you are not prepared to call on the Prime Minister to act, it means that nobody in the Government has any ability at all to act when matters concerning the propriety of ministerial behaviour come into question. Indeed, Madam Speaker, your ruling throws wholly into doubt the circumstances of the behaviour of government under the system which you in this Parliament are called on to administer.

The Prime Minister has a unique responsibility. As we see it, the Prime Minister is called on to act in response to us through questions without notice and, within this Parliament, he is called on to do so for all those matters that are within the ministerial responsibility of government. You know, Madam Speaker: The Minister is not here; the Prime Minister can be called on to answer questions with respect to his portfolio. You, Madam Speaker, know that it is only the Prime Minister who has any responsibility for the whole embrace of government. Here, as in the Senate, there is one person-the Leader of the Government. And the Leader of the Government in this House is the Prime Minister.

Madam Speaker, what you have done specifically with this question is say that it is not for the Prime Minister to be concerned what assertions, inferences or whatever slurs might have been made by the Treasurer about him are appropriate. I find that an absolutely incredible doctrine. It is important for those of us in this Parliament to be able to ask questions of the Prime Minister about ministerial behaviour. Your ruling, Madam Speaker, suggests that the Prime Minister has no responsibility for ministerial behaviour. Your ruling, Madam Speaker, denies any responsibility in this place for anything that a Treasurer or other Minister might say relating to the behaviour of any other Minister. That the Prime Minister is not responsible for ministerial behaviour is an absolute fantasy, Madam Speaker. Your ruling has no bearing in our Westminster system. Your ruling denies the very basis by which Ministers in this place must be seen as answerable to the Prime Minister. Madam Speaker, I strongly put to you that you should reflect on the nature of your ruling. I believe you should advise this House in what way and on what basis in future you will be able to give us a person to whom we can properly ask questions relating to ministerial behaviour.

Is it true that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr Richardson) in the other place can say what they like on the telephone about the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and it does not matter? Madam Speaker, you might feel that it does not matter. We believe it goes to the crux of the Prime Minister's responsibility for his Ministers. Indeed, my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) commented yesterday that he felt there were occasions when a leader has some sensitivity about car telephone conversations, and I believe it is not inappropriate that the Prime Minister might reflect on the way in which action might or might not be taken against his colleague. I know how close and chummy they are. I know how brotherly love is reflected in the very way they smile in this place. But I also know that when they get away from here it is amazing how that friendliness seems to dissipate.

Madam Speaker, I put to you that it is important that there be an opportunity, above all, for you to allow the Prime Minister to accept responsibility for the behaviour of his colleagues. All joking aside, Madam Speaker, I am afraid it is important in this place that the doctrine of Westminster responsibility give to the Prime Minister the responsibility that our system bestows upon him. Madam Speaker, your ruling denies us any opportunity to question matters relating to ministerial propriety and to question ministerial attitudes and their relationship to the Prime Minister. Madam Speaker, I put to you that your ruling in that sense is totally false and totally wrong and should be withdrawn and reconsidered. I very much regret that the ruling, to me, goes quite against the continued practice in this Parliament of the Prime Minister being responsible for the behaviour of his Ministers. I believe you were totally wrong in the ruling you gave.

We know what is going on. We know why the Government is so embarrassed that it has compromised its Speaker into stopping questions relating to any matter of administration. Of course, Madam Speaker, it is outrageous that the Opposition is denied the right to ask these questions. But it is even worse that the Prime Minister clearly does not want to answer. Of course, it is even worse that after 24 hours the Treasurer is showing such arrogant disregard of his Prime Minister as to not deny these allegations. He brushes them aside in his usual arrogant fashion because he has an arrogant disregard for his Prime Minister.

But, Madam Speaker, there is no reason whatsoever for the Chair to have an arrogant disregard for the Parliament. There are rights which we all obtain or achieve when we are elected to this place. Madam Speaker, the Standing Orders are clear on this matter, and the responsibilities of the Prime Minister in this situation are quite clear. Madam Speaker, please let me repeat to you the question, in case in haste you did not hear it correctly. The question that I put to the Prime Minister was:

We might have asked of the Prime Minister, `Why are you such a wimp that you have failed to demand of your Treasurer that he should either deny these allegations categorically, and preferably in this place, or admit to them and apologise to you?'.

—Yes, I think I should remind the honourable member for O'Connor that it is the Chair that is under attack, not the Prime Minister. Would you please get back to the motion of dissent.

—In returning to that motion, let me remind you again that we are dealing with the right of the Opposition to question Ministers of the Government. Standing Orders provide:

SPEECH.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which he is responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will return to the dissent motion. The House is attacking me, not the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the most galling feature of this dissent motion is to have to sit here and suffer the unction of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who is repeatedly disciplined in this place for abusing the forms of the House in Question Time. SPEECH.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected-

to proceedings pending in the House-

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and the Medical Workforce entitled Australian Medical Education and Workforce into the 21st Century. I seek leave to make a brief statement on the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members have already been sent a copy of the report during the parliamentary recess, but I consider it appropriate that it be tabled in view of its importance and significance to medical education and work force planning for the next decade. I should like to extend my sincere thanks and appreciation to Professor Ralph Doherty and the other members of the Committee for their magnificent efforts in producing a report of which they should be justly proud. It is a report of high quality that will provide valuable guidance to governments, medical organisations and medical education institutions for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: In a relatively short time the Committee managed to review, in a most thorough way, all levels of medical education-undergraduate, specialist and continuing-as well as the current and future size, composition and distribution of the medical work force. As one would expect from an inquiry covering such a wide range of subjects, the report is substantial and contains over 100 recommendations. The Government is currently assessing the report and its recommendations and will be moving quickly to establish its priorities in relation to those recommendations that directly affect its areas of responsibility. Many of the recommendations, of course, are directed at State governments, medical schools, medical boards, specialist colleges, and other organisations. The Government is in touch with these parties and it will make every effort to ensure that the recommendations are appropriately considered. The inquiry, and the debate and decisions that will flow from its report, will provide valuable assistance to the Government, which is committed to promoting a medical work force that is appropriately trained and of appropriate size, composition and distribution for the needs of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Acknowledging the other demands on the Parliament today, I will speak briefly. The Opposition also congratulates Professor Doherty and his Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and the Medical Workforce on the excellent work they have done. I am sure that it will be beneficial to the oppositions and governments of today and of the future. We will be very pleased to respond to the Government's response in due course. We will use many of the decisions and advice in that in terms of our own policy formation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Hawke Government's failure to act fairly and democratically in promoting the four referendum questions to be put before the Australian people on 3 September 1988.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House have had a great deal of respect for the Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen). He has been an ornament to his cause. He has been our political foe and political enemy. We have not agreed with his political line, but we have respected that he has been a punter who sometimes makes it and sometimes does not. But on this occasion we disagree not only with what he is punting on next Saturday but also with the way in which he and the Government have conducted the whole referendum campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: Never has a referendum campaign in this country been conducted with such deceit, misleading questions and misleading campaigning and, frankly, on occasions, with the appearance, if not the substance, of fiddling the system. The presentation of the television advertisements was adjudged not by the Parliament but by a court of law to have been a false presentation and to have been a presentation that was biased. The presentation, using the taxpayers' money to present allegedly objective material, was knocked out of court because of the bias which was evident. My office has been flooded with calls from concerned citizens raising the question of the biased presentation of the booklet that has been sent around-with the large `yeses' and the small `noes'. Add to that the ticks and the crosses controversy and we have a pretty sleazy campaign run by a government which has not been fair dinkum with the people on the propositions that are being put on Saturday.
We have termed the matter of public importance:
The Hawke Government's failure to act fairly and democratically in promoting the four referendum questions to be put before the Australian people on 3 September 1988.

Question 2 calls on the people of Australia to vote for `fair and democratic elections'. The question is neither fair nor democratic in the manner in which the campaign has been conducted. Like all four questions, the simple questions being put to the people are highly misleading. Frankly, if the Government were trying to sell its case in the world of commerce, in the private sector, rather than simply shovelling out the taxpayers' money to pay for this campaign, it would be dragged before the Trade Practices Commission.

If the Government wants fair elections, what about some fair questions? Question 2, on fair and democratic elections, is unfair and undemocratic because the Government has brazenly biased the question towards a yes vote. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has criss-crossed this country plausibly and strongly arguing the No case. The evidence and the trend, as a consequence of the effectiveness of his arguments, are shown as the polling is coming down. I can say to the Attorney that he will not succeed on Saturday. I have said to him that question 2, on fair and democratic elections, is unfair and undemocratic because the Government has biased the question towards a Yes vote.

However, it is also unfair and undemocratic because people are being deprived of the opportunity to make an informed decision. They are being asked whether they favour `fair and democratic elections', when the supporting Bill is actually a complex document adding 13 new clauses to and deleting five clauses from the Australian Constitution. People think that they are answering four questions and that there will be only four changes to the Constitution. There will be an abundance of changes to Constitution that was put together with a spirit of goodwill among men who accepted that the government of the day that put referenda questions would put them fairly and honestly. If the question was phrased according to fair and democratic principles, it would ask the people whether they believed that the Federal Government should have the power to impose rules upon and to intervene in State election matters.

Honourable members will recall that debate on the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill was gagged-a sleaze element which I did not think would have intruded into a referendum campaign, but which has been so much a part of the conduct of this Government in action. The sleaze element which brought in these misleading questions and gagged effective democratic debate in this country has gone on throughout the campaign to stifle debate and the manner in which the referenda are conducted.

The Bill does not put an end to gerrymanders. What it will mean is that the people in, say, Sydney and Melbourne will be telling people in Tasmania or Western Australia how to run their State elections and how to run their State parliaments. Furthermore, the Bill has the potential to invalidate existing procedures for some State parliaments. Unquestionably, it could destabilise the whole electoral process in some States. The mistakes in the Bill, admitted by the Government, and the manner in which the Bill was subsequently amended in the Senate undoubtedly demonstrate the slipshod manner in which the legislation was prepared and rushed through the Parliament.

Let us be blunt and to the point: Frankly, question No. 2 is about political manipulation and expedience. It should be rejected on those grounds alone. I remind the House of what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has so succinctly put in regard to these questions. He has said on behalf of this side of the House that we oppose the first question because it will dramatically weaken the Senate, thereby hurting the smaller States. He has said that we oppose the second question because the electoral boundaries of the States should be fixed by the parliaments of the States. I do not understand why we bother to have States at all if someone in this place is to determine their actions. Thirdly, he said that we oppose the third question because, local government having been created by the States, it is only right and proper that local government should be entrenched in and protected by the constitutions of the States and not the Constitution of the Commonwealth. Local government bodies are creatures of the States. They exist as a consequence of State legislation, not as a consequence of the Commonwealth. We oppose the fourth question out of a passionate belief that any attempt to define in complete detail a basic human right renders the risk, through inadvertent omission, that such rights will be restricted rather than expanded. Collectively, the four proposals increase Canberra's power and weaken our federal structure. That, succinctly, is what the Opposition Leader has put so accurately in terms of the Opposition's view of the referenda questions on Saturday.

When the leading citizens, or those who thought they were, came together in the constitutional conventions of the 1890s they put together a Constitution which, whilst implementing the Westminster system of government, looked at the United States in terms of the division of powers. They deliberately wrote in a number of constraints. For example, the Executive was constrained and answerable to the Parliament. The Parliament was answerable to the people. No-one had unfettered powers. Interestingly enough, not even the people have unfettered powers because the people's view is actually constrained in regard to the manner in which a referendum is determined. It is not by a vote of the majority of the people; it is by a vote of the majority of the people in the majority of the States.

Every element of fairness that was laid down in the Constitution exuded the spirit of goodwill of those conventions. This is the very thing that has been lacking throughout this campaign. There has been no spirit of goodwill towards the people. To be precise, $41m has been spent on this referenda campaign. This is not the Government's money; it is the taxpayers' money. The referenda are not being held in harness with an election campaign; they have been dumped out. For what reason? We thought that perhaps it was because Government members were going to go into some jingoistic campaign, beating their breasts and proclaiming what great nationalists they were. In fact, they have tried to do it the other way. They decided to shovel out the money and let the campaign be quietly conducted so that people really would not see that so many of the checks, balances and constraints which I have just mentioned and which are written into the Constitution would bypass the argument and, therefore, allow them to have more power in the Parliament. The mob in government are great collectivists. They deal with the trade unions and the big corporations on the basis that the more they can centralise power the more control they have over this nation-a nation which was founded on a Constitution that has effective checks and balances which honourable members opposite have been seeking to override. Not only did honourable members opposite sweep that aside; they swept aside conventions. They swept aside practices which have been adopted over a period and which have become what are generally termed in the law conventions.

In January the Attorney-General gave the four questions he wanted in the referendum to the Constitutional Commission. This Commission was set up by the Government to advise it on how to run the referendum and on what changes ought to be made to the Constitution. But that was not good enough for the Attorney. He might have had a bad day at the races-I do not know-but he said, `You will do these four things'. He told the Constitutional Commission what he wanted. The Government then used the opening of the new Parliament House, this magnificent new building, to encourage the Yes vote. Honourable members have seen the advertisements. They were beautifully presented. They depicted the new Parliament House and we were led to believe, by implication, that we ought to have a new Constitution. All the shavings of the honest and objective conventions of the past were moved aside by the use of an emotive influence in the advertisements.

The Government asked itself, `When will we have the referendum?' On the basis of steering away from having too much attention directed to the matter, the Government decided to have it two weeks after the Budget. The Government thought-this was prior to Graham cruising the streets of Canberra or wherever with a car phone in hand-that the Budget would dominate and that therefore there would be no opportunity for argument on the referenda. As I said, in terms of the breaking of conventions, the questions are undeniably, on the basis of any objective test, biased towards a Yes vote.

I have said that debate on the Bills was gagged in the Parliament. It is a reasonable convention in this country to have effective parliamentary debate. However, the Attorney has gagged debate on something as essential as a referendum campaign. The Attorney has refused constantly to debate publicly the issues with the honourable member for Flinders. I have seen the Attorney-General on television. He bobs up on the box in one studio, but he will not enter the same studio as the honourable member for Flinders and have a debate with him. I know what I did to the Prime Minister in the 1984 election campaign. But fair go! Four years later the Government ought to have got over that traumatic experience and be prepared to have a go at him. If the Attorney thinks he has the arguments, he should be prepared to sit in a studio and debate the issues with the honourable member for Flinders. Whether it is the manipulative television campaign, the dodging of debates with the honourable member for Flinders or the dodging of debates in this Parliament, the Attorney-General has twisted the normal conventions to override. At the end of the day, the taxpayers will be paying for even his own Party's advertising agency to produce the ads. We have the old technique of shoving the money off to the Government's mates. I dare say a bit of the money has gone back to the Party as a donation from the profits that have been made. But taxpayers' money is being used to produce a so-called objective advertising campaign.

The next point I raise relates to the four questions. As I have said, these four simple questions will involve 33 changes. That means that in one day, at one referendum, there will be more changes proposed to the Constitution than all the amendments to the Constitution since Federation. There will be 33 separate changes involving a repeal of nine clauses, the insertion of 20 clauses and the amendment of four clauses. Like a thief in the night, the Government has snuck this through, expecting people to buy it. Well, the people will not. If the Attorney-General, as a punter, is out at Randwick, or wherever the races are, on Saturday he will find that this quadrella is down the drain. He should look at another four on Saturday when assessing the form, because I think these ones were nobbled from the start. People have woken up to the Government. If we were on the track there would be a stewards inquiry. I remind the Attorney that there have been 38 referenda since 1901, only eight have been approved, and only one of these was a Labor initiative. The people do not trust the Government on this matter and the Government will find out on Saturday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always refreshing to hear the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). He adds a touch of class to this place. He understands how to present an argument, even though we do not have to agree with it. He does not lose his temper; he has a controlled emotion. He is able to put forward a case with a fair amount of skill. I welcome the remarks he made about me. They sounded like Mark Antony's speech over the dead body of Caesar, but we will not go into that because I have a lot of affection for the honourable member for Kooyong. I do not know why he was raising the issue of how well he went in the 1984 election, because he seems to have lost his prime poll position since that time. That might relate to talking on car telephones.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to come to the issue of what we are trying to do here. The point that we are about is what the people are interested in at the referendum on Saturday. The honourable gentleman is very anxious to say that the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has done a very good job, and he has. But he will not debate with me here. All the matters of public importance have been brought on by somebody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wanted to bring on the leaders, and you brought the leaders on.

—Could the honourable member give me a little bit of quiet. We had two matters of public importance last week. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was absent. He was doing his job out in the country, trying to get the votes up whilst leaving this matter to somebody else. Today, because there is some suggestion of a leadership challenge coming up, everybody has to make a run and impress the back bench. So now we have another matter of public importance. I want to reject completely the view that I have been up on my feet for the last two weeks in Parliament arguing the Government's case whilst my opposite number has not been here-admittedly he does not want to be here. He would rather be somewhere else where people do not know as much about the issue. I do know a little about the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put at rest completely the suggestions that there is some deceit about this matter. We cannot do this with the Opposition but the gallery might be interested. The point I want to make is that the Constitutional Commission brought out its first report, in a preliminary way, on the first referendum question last October. We debated it here with the greatest of intensity. The Opposition said that it was outrageous to be suggesting that there was going to be a joint sitting of the Houses when we had a disagreement. I accepted that. The Opposition has been saying sotto voce, `What a dreadful thing it is that the Attorney- General hasn't agreed with the second proposal, the second chance for the Commission'. That was that we could not pass any legislation in the first three years and the Senate could not throw us out in the first three years. I read-and I think I read it right-that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would not want the Senate so inhibited or restricted. I would be amazed if the Senate would allow to pass a law saying that senators could not do anything for three years.

Let us get this issue right. There is this suggestion of deceit because I did not use the recommendations of the Commission. I used what I thought would be a fair analysis of the proposition for the first question that we ought not to inhibit the powers of the Senate, and that is the way the first question is phrased. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is here, and I respect that. We had a discussion about four-year terms and he agreed with them, on the one condition that the Senate have eight-year terms. We cannot give the Senate eight-year terms, because we would have the position of senators--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have got it through.

—But the Leader of the Opposition would have changed his mind. The Leader of the Opposition said, `Look, I think it is a bit hard to ask for eight years'. I am certain it is. Senators would get a parliamentary pension after one win. They would be so far removed from reality that they would not care less what they did. The point the honourable member wants to come to is what we are about in the first question. It is not deceitful. The fact is that there should be fewer elections. The first question does away with the need for half Senate elections. It does away with the reasons that Prime Ministers have been giving-when they have gone to the Governor-General-that they want to keep the Houses in kilter. They do not have that any more. I have no hope of convincing the Opposition of this, because it has made up its mind; but the people ought to understand that when we are putting forward the question of four-year terms it is a legitimate question. It is on the basis that we will have fewer elections because those explanations given in the past will no longer be valid. That is very clear. We cannot stop double dissolutions if the Senate rejects legislation twice-nobody has argued that-but the Senate comes out in toto. Nobody objects to that. The Commission said, `We have not had a six-year senator elected since December 1964'. The Opposition has been in power for most of that time. The number of dissolutions which those opposite sought is very significant. On that basis we want to make the Senate accountable for the position of Supply. It is a reasonable situation. If the Senate, quite legitimately in its view, said, `It is a bad government; they are out' we would have eight-year senators sitting there saying, `Terrific. We don't have to come out'. That is the position.
—I offered you that as well.
—The point that we are about is--
—He is right.
—If I could only have my time uninterrupted. The Opposition is so worried about the weakness of its case. The Leader of the Opposition said, `What about five years for both?'
—That was the Prime Minister.
—No, it was not.
—If the Leader of the Opposition continues to interject I will name him.

—I know that the Leader of the Opposition is getting excited. He had one of these goes himself. I would probably get more sense out of the honourable member for Flinders by way of interjection, because at least he knows what the subject is about.
—The Attorney-General should not respond to interjections.

—I am responding to the argument that there is deceit and misleading advertising. Another allegation was that we had done something illegal. We offered it to the Electoral Commissioner, who got the opinion of two Queen's Counsel and he said, `It is in order'. We will accept the judgment. That is what happened. We did nothing. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition then says, `What a dreadful thing it is'. Look at the way the case is printed. I will give a few marks to the Yes case but look at that No case. It is very difficult to read; it is a jumble of words'. The presentation was made by each side.
—And never before have they been done in that way.

—Can I just continue uninterrupted? Each case was presented and the typeset was made that way. We were not impressed to have our Yes set alongside a No either but we had nothing to do with it. The people will wonder what the blazes they are reading when they come to this. It had nothing to do with us, because we had the independence of the Electoral Commissioner.
—So he was responsible for the pamphlet?
—He was responsible for the layout, the lot. It is a matter of record. There were discussions with the Opposition regarding the typesetting arrangements. That is the way it went because--
—So we had big yeses and small noes?

—Order! There is far too much interjecting on my left. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence. The Attorney-General should be heard in silence. I would ask the Attorney-General not to respond to the interjections, although it is not his fault that people are interjecting.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The point that I am trying to make is that it is very clear that people can always cast aspersions on somebody and suggest that they are doing the wrong thing. Nothing wrong has been done here. The questions mean what they say. They relate to the Constitutional Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I have dealt with the first question. The other three questions relate directly to evidence given to the Constitutional Commission. The honourable member for Kooyong spent a fair bit of time saying that it was quite unfair to be talking about fair and democratic elections. He went on to say that we should not be trying to do that and that we should leave it to the States because that was what we had States for. The honourable gentleman knows that when evidence was given to the Commission it was on behalf of people in those States, in Queensland and Western Australia, saying how outrageous it was to have a rorting of boundaries and a weighting of votes three to one simply because a party wanted to rely on a minority to be a government.

Russ Hinze has been able to say, with some eloquence, that he carried the National Party, that some of the seats in Queensland were rigged to the extent that all one had to do was get a National Party tag and one could win it forever and a day. He is right. That has brought bad government in Queensland. It is corrupt. That is known to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. The Queensland Government called the Parliament together for only 49 days last year. It did not care less about the Parliament. It was a Government of patronage, privilege and cronyism. That is what the Queensland people are up against on this occasion. What is the good of them going to that Government and saying, `Are you going to make the boundaries fair?' Fancy talking to the executioner about whether he is going to spare your life! No chance. That is exactly what happened. But members of the Liberal Party have enough gumption and fairness to say, `Listen, we are into this. We want fair elections'. The only way they can get them is by having boundaries under which they know they have a chance of increasing their membership in parliament and possibly winning an election. Why do members of the Opposition want to deny that? The Government of Western Australia is saying, `We want fair boundaries'. Again, the boundaries in that State are rorted to suit the upper House in the ratio of 3:1. The Western Australian Government cannot get fair boundaries through the upper House, but it is asking the people of Australia to legitimise fair electoral distribution. There is nothing wrong with that. The people have been asked to vote on whether they think it is a fair thing for a fair go, and I am sure that they will say `Yes'. Then it is up to the governments of those two States to fix up the boundaries in accordance with the wishes of the people. It is not hard to do. Every member elected to this House of Representatives from across Australia, including Queensland and Western Australia, is elected on fair boundaries. That is not a problem.

Why do members of the Opposition have this lust for power? Why do they say, `We want to remain in power. Even though the boundaries are crook and corrupt we are going to stay'? They should look at the results they have got. That is why they ought to look at the situation as Australians. They should not look at it from the point of view that, because they are always in opposition, they have always got to say no.

I read out today the list, the litany, of those in favour of the recognition of local government. Why are members of the Opposition so outrageous that they cannot even agree with the proposition that local government is deserving of recognition? They have got to understand that local government is not at all impressed. The Local Government Association wrote to Mr Howard on 25 August, saying:
I am writing to appeal to your sense of fair play.

I am sure he will find it one day, but on this occasion the situation was that the honourable member for Flinders was out there saying all sorts of things and local government was saying, `This is outrageous':
This morning on the Mike Carlton radio show Mr Reith stated that Local Government Associations . . . are dumping the Yes case. These are blatant lies . . .
That is what has been said. The honourable member has to wear that. Local government said, `They are blatant lies'. Look at the policy of the Liberal Party. The issue is this--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask the Attorney-General to withdraw that.
—I was just about to call the Attorney--

—I will withdraw it, but the honourable member for Flinders has not made any personal explanation. His leader has had the letter since 25 August. I would have thought the honourable member for Flinders would have been up in the House explaining his conduct. I withdraw it for the honourable member. But, listen, this is what the Local Government Association has written about him. Do not try to square it off with me. I accept the honourable member's view, but the Local Government Association does not.

SPEECH.PARA: Given another couple of minutes, I will deal with the other two questions. The issues of trial by jury and fair compensation were in the honourable member for Sydney's last platform of reform at the time we went to the last elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not your words.

—What was that? Speechless again; all right. When asked why all this was happening, the honourable member stated, `I am damned if I know'. He said, `I am damned if I know why the Opposition will not support questions Nos. 3 and 4'. We are all in the same boat as the honourable member on that issue because there is no danger or deceit in those questions.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, question No. 1 means fewer elections. Question No. 2 entrenches in the Constitution the right to vote, which Australians have not got following McKinlay's case, fair voting, recognition of local government, and the extension of the democratic rights that already exist. If the honourable gentleman is not convinced by my advocacy, he is worried about the Budget Speech coming on this day. He knows that it takes the Electoral Commissioner 100 days to send out the Yes and No cases. We passed the legislation through the Senate in the first week in June. If we add about three months to the first week in June, we get to 3 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—I mentioned to the Leader of the Opposition previously that I thought the most appropriate time to call him to make a personal explanation was at the end of this debate. It is my recollection that it has been the practice of the House for personal explanations to be made during breaks in the proceedings. I understand that there is an arrangement between the parties that there shall be two more speakers on this matter.
—Are you refusing me leave?
—I am quite willing to call the Leader of the Opposition at the end of this debate.
—Are you refusing me leave?

—The Leader of the Opposition may also be aware that there is a provision in the Standing Orders that this debate may proceed for two hours. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to take part in the debate, there is no doubt that debate can continue for that two hours, though in the past there have been agreements from the parties to limit the speakers to two a side. I think that, in conformance with previous practice, I should call the Leader of the Opposition at the end of this matter of public importance.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on other occasions people have been allowed, in relation to matters that are relevant to debates under consideration, to make personal explanations. If you are refusing me leave I simply note the fact that the indulgence normally accorded to leaders of the parties in this Parliament is not being adhered to on this occasion. The Opposition will carefully note that.
—It is a special position.

—My recollection is that there is no special concession for leaders of either side to break into the middle of debates, unless they are willing to explain something that they were debating; and there are substantial differences in those two arrangements.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would like you to just reflect on the ruling that you have given, and I give you an opportunity to rethink, without losing face, what you have said and to reverse it. To the best of my knowledge--
—If the honourable member for Hume can put to me a case in the past where this has occurred, I am quite willing to hear him; but I do not recall a case in the past myself.

—To the best of my knowledge, there is nothing in the Standing Orders that would prevent the Leader of the Opposition making a personal explanation now. I submit to you that you should permit him to do so because he is not participating in this debate and what he wishes to explain to the House is relevant to the debate. In those circumstances I put it to you, in a very sincere way and in the interests of the good running and harmony of this House, that you permit the Leader of the Opposition to make his personal explanation forthwith.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, further on the point of order, I submit in support of the honourable member for Hume that Madam Speaker has, on previous occasions in rulings and intimations from the Chair, said words to the effect that leaders of parties in this House do have certain leeway in the proceedings of this House; and that is what we are asking you to recognise on this occasion.

—There is no doubt that certain indulgence is given by the Chair to leaders of parties, but I doubt whether that indulgence should go to the extent of breaking into the middle of a debate to allow a party leader to make a personal explanation. The party leader may take part in the debate if he wishes, or he may wait for the other two speakers-I imagine they are going to speak for only 10 minutes each, which is the normal course of this debate-and I most certainly will then give him the call. I think it is inappropriate that we should have people seeking in the middle of debates to make personal explanations. It is no doubt appropriate that a person who has taken part in a debate and is then misrepresented further along the way by another person in that debate should be able to seek the call to explain where he was misrepresented, but I do not think it is appropriate that someone who has not participated in the debate should be able to break in.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on that issue, may I submit to you, with respect, on a further point of order, that the explanation you have given would make sense if the subject matter of my personal explanation was unrelated to the subject matter of the debate. I can understand that. But in the course of his speech, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) made an observation about me which is untrue. It goes to the very core of the debate now under way and a correction of that allegation is material to a conclusion of this debate in an objective fashion.

—Then there is nothing to stop the Leader of the Opposition exercising the prerogative that is usually given to Leaders of the Opposition or the Government by their own parties by standing, seeking the call and participating in the debate. I do not propose to allow a personal explanation now.

—I note that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are abrogating a longstanding practice of this House to grant a certain degree of indulgence to Party leaders. If that is the pattern by which the Government is going to run this House, then the character of the House will change.

—I put it to the Leader of the Opposition that this is not a matter that is anything to do with the Government. It is something I am doing now in conformity with my understanding of how this debate has run over a number of years. I will call the next speaker on my left in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The flippant but totally dishonest charge flung by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) at the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is typical of the sordid, deceitful campaign that has marked the conduct of this referendum. I believe, as do all honourable members on this side of the House, that the charge he made against the Leader of the Opposition, almost as an aside, is of such a serious nature that it deserves to be answered by the Leader of the Opposition on the spot.

SPEECH.PARA: This referendum campaign has been a very sorry exercise in partisan politics. If the Attorney-General wanted to make the campaign his last major achievement in a lifetime in politics, then I am sorry to have to say that he is leaving under a cloud. The Government has been biased and it has not been open and honest at any time during this campaign. This is the easiest brief for any lawyer to argue. We should have known that the conduct of the campaign would be biased and deceitful when the Labor Government abolished the Constitutional Convention, made up of Federal, State and local government representatives, and replaced it two years ago with its hand-picked Constitutional Commission. At a cost of $6m, that Commission set about tramping all over Australia arguing the case for the need for changes to the Constitution. That was of great assistance to the Government. The strategy of the Government was to capitalise on the bicentennial euphoria that has surrounded 1988. Some years ago Senator Gareth Evans gave us a clue about the Government's strategy for 1988 when, on 30 March 1983, he said:

If we really build a momentum to 1988, succeed with fixed-term Parliaments, get in place a popularly elected convention, we have the potential to set in train some quite major structural reforms which will affect the quality of the way Australia is governed for decades to come.

That tells us two things: first, that Labor was always going to capitalise on 1988; and, secondly, that these are not merely minor changes to the Constitution, but major fundamental changes to our system of government as well as to a number of our long held values and traditions.

To continue the list of rorts in which the Government has engaged during the past few months, we note that the time allowed for debates about the referendum is only three months. The Bills were introduced on 10 May and they will be voted on on 3 September. Yet the Referendum Machinery Act allows six months. By the Government's own legislation it could have allowed six months, yet we are left with three months. As the Government realises now from opinion polls, these referendum questions will be defeated on Saturday. Is it any wonder that the Government wanted to cut the time for debate to an absolute minimum?

Let us now refer to the wording of the questions. There would not be one single person in this chamber, on either side of the House, who really believes that the questions convey the true meaning of the changes to the Constitution. Leaving aside the phraseology, how can four questions properly summarise 33 changes to the Constitution-20 additions, eight deletions and five amendments? A total of 33 changes are hidden behind seemingly innocuous, bland questions. We need only refer to the words of the Managing Director of the Roy Morgan Research Centre, Mr Gary Morgan, when he said a couple of months ago:
Any public opinion polling company who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility.

The Government has engaged in a fraud. But it does not stop there. The Government has run for cover at every turn of the debate surrounding the referendum. This Attorney-General will not accept any invitation to debate the issues. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has, on numerous occasions, challenged him to a debate, as have a number of media outlets, including the National Press Club. Yet the Attorney-General steadfastly refuses to debate the issues except in the parliamentary context where he makes a number of rambling, almost incoherent explanations about the four questions. Again, the Attorney-General revealed himself when he said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio earlier this week:
The Government's low key approach to the four questions has worked well so far . . .
He went on to say that no politicians in the Labor Government should get involved. In fact, his exact quote is:
The ALP machinery should not come into the debate at such a late stage. They've never been involved in it. This has been a different campaign because I wanted to keep politicians out.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—The Attorney-General agrees that politicians, representing as we do so much of the Australian electorate, should not have a say. Between us, the Opposition and the Government members represent 100 per cent of the Australian electorate, yet the Attorney-General has muzzled his own members. We on this side will not be muzzled. When the results of the vote are known next Saturday the Attorney-General will be totally and utterly repudiated. The rorts-there is no other word for it-and the fraud and the lying continued with the rigged tele- vision campaign at the expense of $3m.

In fact, the script was not even subtle. Honourable members on this side laugh at it because it was so obvious to any bush lawyer that the Government had attempted to influence the referendum. DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NATIONAL MEDICAL CYCLOTRON FACILITY, ROYAL PRINCE ALFRED HOSPITAL, SYDNEY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of National Medical Cyclotron facility, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney.

The proposed public work provides for the construction of a building at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney to house the national medical cyclotron, associated laboratories and facilities for radiopharmaceutical production. The work also includes refurbishment of a nearby patient clinical facility to house a positron emission tomography (PET) camera and a rapid transfer system linking it with the cyclotron building.

The need for a medical cyclotron in Australia has been mooted for almost 20 years. The present proposal is the outcome of extensive objective appraisal by Government, the Australian scientific and medical communities and invited experts from overseas with significant experience in cyclotrons and the introduction of new medical technologies.

The national medical cyclotron will have a significant impact on the future of diagnostic nuclear medicine in Australia. It will be used to produce radioisotopes for the immediate medical application of ultra short-life radioisotopes in the clinical PET centre facility at Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney, and for nationwide distribution, to other major hospitals in Australia, of the longer life radioisotopes used in other medical applications. In this latter role, the cyclotron will complement the reactor HIFAR at Lucas Heights and will ensure that the complete range of radioisotopes is, for the first time, readily accessible to medicine in Australia.

The cyclotron and associated laboratories will be housed in the one building. It will comprise a basement for the storage and treatment of radioactive waste, a ground floor to accommodate the cyclotron and laboratories, and a first floor for offices and plant room. The cyclotron will be the focus of the building and will be housed within a 1.9 metre thick concrete vault. Careful consideration has been given to the safe handling of radioactive substances, drawing on 25 years relevant experience at the Lucas Heights research laboratories. To prevent accidental releases, the facility has been designed on the principle of double containment and all waste products will be controlled.

An essential feature of the total proposal is the refurbishment of part of the second floor of the hospital's Albert Pavilion to house the PET centre in the mainstream clinical area. The PET camera weighs two tonnes and is being funded separately by the hospital and will greatly enhance the hospital's diagnostic and research capabilities. Patients will inhale or receive an injection of small amounts of radioactive tracer processed through the pharmaceutical laboratories which are integral with the cyclotron building. The gamma rays emitted by the tracer are detected by the PET camera which surrounds the patient. The information is computer processed to produce cross sectional maps of the trace distribution within patients.

The third major component of the work is the construction of a transfer system to deliver the products of the cyclotron to the patients in the PET centre. Because of the very short radioactive half lives of the radioisotopes used in PET, their time in transit must be minimal. The cyclotron building will be linked to the PET centre by an underground conduit between the buildings. The cyclotron building has been designed to follow the pavilion style of other buildings in the hospital complex.

The Council of the City of Sydney has approved a development application for the proposal and the New South Wales State authorities are satisfied that the requirements of the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 have been met. In the light of these approvals which clearly indicate that the cyclotron will not have a significant impact on the environment, my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is responsible for the proposal, is satisfied that the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 do not need to be invoked. Neither the Heritage Council of New South Wales nor the National Trust of Australia has objected to the demolition of existing buildings that is implicit in the proposal.

The limit of cost estimate for the building works totals $8.9m at January 1988 prices. This is slightly less than half the total project cost, including equipment, consultant fees and training et cetera. Early consideration by the Public Works Committee is required in order to secure the benefit of the tendered price for the preferred cyclotron type before the expiry of the validity period at the end of this year. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation proposes to manage and supervise construction of the cyclotron as well as the installation and commissioning of major equipment. In collaboration, the hospital planning staff will manage and supervise construction of the PET facility and transfer link. Total completion is envisaged in about 20 months from approval. I table plans and details of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the reference of this proposal to the Joint Committee on Public Works. I do not know the answer to that and I would therefore like the Committee to report on it. I understand that it is within the terms of reference of the Public Works Committee.

The other matter that I raise results from the fact that the short radioactive half-life of the radioisotopes used in PET means their time in transit must be minimal. The Government has obviously taken a decision to establish only one of these units. As described by the Minister, the cost of this is $8.9m for half the total project cost. It is quite an expensive project. The Public Works Committee ought to look at whether this is the best way to go. I think that the Austin Hospital in Melbourne wanted a similar plant. I am not sure whether there are smaller cyclotron facilities now available which are capable of being purchased by the Government. Perhaps we could have smaller facilities in a couple of the major capital cities instead of putting all our eggs in one basket.

Again, I do not know the answer to that. It may not be technologically or economically feasible to introduce this new technology into two hospitals in Australia rather than only Sydney. I would again like some answers. I remember that at the time it was a matter of debate as to which hospital or which couple of hospitals would get this facility. I imagine that debate is continuing. Whilst I do not want to take the project away from Sydney, if it is possible to introduce a couple of these facilities-perhaps in Sydney and Melbourne-and if it is current technology, the Australian community would be well served.

The third point that the Committee will want to review is whether, given the advice from the specialist committees, this is wise expenditure of the health dollar. DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF NEW UTILITY HELICOPTER FACILITIES, RAAF BASE, TOWNSVILLE AND OAKEY ARMY AIRFIELD, QUEENSLAND

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provision of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of new utility helicopter facilities, phases 2, at Royal Australian Air Force Base, Townsville and Oakey Army Airfield, Qld.

The proposed work is for the provision of operational support and administrative facilities at Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Base, Townsville, and Oakey Army Airfield in support of the second phase of delivery of the new Sikorsky Black Hawk helicopters. The proposal was referred to the Public Works Committee on 14 April 1988 and the Committee has duly reported to the Parliament recommending the construction of the facilities. Construction of the Phase 1 works at RAAF Base, Townsville, which are for facilities to accommodate a squadron to be equipped with the first 14 of the Black Hawk helicopters, was approved by the House in April 1987. A number of these facilities have been completed and occupied by the Army. The remaining works will be completed shortly.

Since that time the purchase of 25 additional helicopters has been approved. Control of these battlefield helicopters is being assumed by the Army over a five year period. To this end the Army is raising a unit known as 5th Aviation Regiment at RAAF Base, Townsville, which will provide tactical air support to combat elements of the operational deployment force. Once the Black Hawk helicopters become operational the Army proposes to conduct conversion and operational training for aircrew and maint- enance personnel at Oakey Army Airfield, 150 kilometres west of Brisbane. At both bases there is a need to upgrade and extend existing operational, technical and administrative facilities to accommodate both new personnel and equipment and the relocation of existing operational units. The proposed work at RAAF Base, Townsville, includes works associated with the Army's new 5th Aviation Regiment and with the relocation of the existing RAAF No. 35 Squadron consisting of the extension and upgrading of buildings for headquarters facilities, flightline facilities, technical support and store facilities; the extension of hangars to accommodate the Black Hawk helicopters and relocated Caribou aircraft and workshop facilities; the provision of new single living in accommodation for 248 persons and the upgrading of security services and engineering services.

When this proposal was referred to the Public Works Committee, I indicated there was a need for additional married quarters in the Townsville area to house the increased married personnel who were associated with the basing of the 5th Aviation Regiment at RAAF Base, Townsville. Provision of these houses was to be undertaken separately by the Defence Housing Authority and was therefore not included in the proposal referred to the Committee. During the hearing of the proposal, the Defence Housing Authority did however provide details to the Committee of the possible number of houses required and the various alternative delivery methods available. The Committee in its report has concluded that this housing should have been referred to the Committee as part of the reference.

I have been advised that although the exact number of houses required and their methods of delivery by the Defence Housing Authority are still to be finalised, the bulk of the housing will be obtained from either available houses from the Defence Housing Authority's existing stock in the Townsville area, or through acquisition of existing and new project homes. Acquisition proposals of this nature are not public works which are required to be referred to the Committee. The number and cost of houses likely to be constructed on Commonwealth land and so be considered a public work would fall well below the $6m figure which would require separate referral to the Committee. Under the circumstances, the briefing of the Committee by the Defence Housing Authority during the public hearing is considered an appropriate method of handling this aspect.

The cost of the facilities at RAAF Base, Townsville, as recommended by the Committee is $19.2m at October 1987 prices. This equates to $20.9m at August 1988 prices. Subject to the approval of the House to proceed, it is intended that construction will commence in late 1988 with completion scheduled by mid-1990. During this construction period the on-site work force is expected to peak at about 100 by mid-1989.

The proposed work at Oakey Army Airfield includes extension of buildings for aircrew training facilities and maintenance personnel training facilities; extension of technical facilities, including a maintenance hangar, workshop and storage facilities; provision of an enclosed aircraft shelter for the six Black Hawk helicopters to be stationed at Oakey; and the extension of the existing aircraft apron and taxiway. The cost of the proposed work at Oakey as recommended by the Committee is $5m at October 1987 prices. This equates to $5.5m at August 1988 prices. Subject to the approval of the House to proceed, construction is planned to commence in early-1989 with a construction time of approximately 10 months. This will allow transfer of training courses to Oakey in early-1990. The on-site work force at Oakey is expected to number about 40 during the peak construction period.
I would like to thank the Committee for the support that it has given to this proposal and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the Government's proposal: it will provide a much needed upgrading of Australian Defence Force facilities. We on the Opposition side have been deeply concerned for some time about the rundown in Defence Force numbers; the lack of appropriate equipment for the defence forces; and the lack of appropriate facilities. Whilst this proposal is only a small step, at least it is a step in the right direction.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise with the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) the concerns of the Joint Committee on Public Works, which I share. I do not accept that excuse. I do not think that the Public Works Committee can do its job with only half a reference. Part of its job is to look at the totality of a project and see whether it is a cost effective way of meeting the goals that the Government has set. By referring only part of a project to the Committee, it cannot do its job properly.

The Government has to get its act together. This is not the first time that we have had instances of referrals with insufficient details being made to the Committee. In some instances, referrals have not been made at all. It appears that the Committee picked up information on these married quarter facilities during the inquiry and took evidence on it. It has made it very clear what its view is. It says:

On the basis of the information provided by the Defence Housing Authority the Committee concludes that the housing is an integral component of the overall project and that the houses to be constructed using the mechanisms of project housing, the house and land package, and land purchase with project homes involve construction and are therefore a public work.

I do not know how the Minister thinks that they do not involve a public work. The excuse he has given today is paper thin; it is pathetic. He would be better off getting these things right at the start rather than coming in here and making pathetic apologies. The Committee's report continues:
As a result, the Committee concludes that the houses to be constructed using those mechanisms should have been referred to the Committee as part of the reference.

I do not question that. I think the Committee is right and the Minister is wrong. It is about time the Minister got his act together. This is not the first time this has happened. I repeat: Whilst we welcome the Public Works Committee's recommendation-my colleague the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) will make some more comments on the defence aspects-we warn the Government that we will be reviewing closely this tendency towards sloppy administration by this Minister in the reference of works to the Public Works Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) on his initiative in putting this motion before the House. This is a wonderful initiative for the Australian Defence Force and also for the economic benefit of the people of Townsville. I would like to thank him also for the enormous amount of work he has done in organisation and administration, and generally seeing to the completion of a wide range of improvements at RAAF Base Garbutt. He has been responsible for the administration and supervision of the upgrading of a major hangar and single airmen's and single airwomen's accommodation-which is now among the best in Australia. In other words, a host of facilities has been upgraded during his time at RAAF Base Garbutt. I believe-I know that my belief is shared by many people in the RAAF-that his services deserve the highest commendation for performance of duty and for service to his country.

I also would like to place on record the thanks of the people of Australia to the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the Vice-Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) and other members of the Committee for the speed with which they have dealt with this particular reference. This project is an urgent one. Phase 2 of the works must be commenced and completed as soon as possible to meet the time frame for delivery of phase 2 of the Black Hawk helicopters. Despite the problems that were encountered in the course of the evidence that was taken at Townsville, I would like to place on record the thanks for the competence with which the members of the Public Works Committee performed their tasks in the taking of evidence, the assessing of evidence and the production of its report. I know that the people reading the record of this debate will place no emphasis whatsoever on the comments made by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note with interest that the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) has spoken to this motion, as well he might. He takes a great deal of interest in defence matters in his own electorate. I also know how important this matter is to him because of the hard time he is getting from all the defence personnel in his area. We support the provision of these facilities in Townsville and in Oakey. It is about time something was done to make life in the Services more bearable and bring it up to scratch-to the same standard and conditions which pertain to the civilian work force.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that this motion has been moved a week or so after the defence budget was brought down in this house. The point must be made that, despite all the posturings of the Government about defence expenditure, the 1988-89 defence budget represents the lowest proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) for the last 40 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 2.4 per cent.

—A defence budget of 2.4 per cent of GDP is the lowest defence budget, as a proportion of GDP, for 40 years. However, honourable members posture in this House and around the country, saying how they are looking after servicemen and how much money is being spent on defence. SPEECH.PARA: The new helicopters are a very necessary addition to the Australian Defence Force (ADF). However, he knows very well that were we required to do something in Fiji, Vanuatu, Noumea or, perhaps, New Guinea-which is looking increasingly unstable-we would not have the capacity to move troops in meaningful numbers. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) comes in here and talks about Australia's capacity to have some influence in the region. The other question which must be raised when talking about Black Hawk helicopters is: Are we really going to have anyone left to fly and maintain them? The ADF in many units is collapsing. The sorriest story of the lot is in the RAAF: 123 pilots left last year. In one month of this financial year 42 RAAF pilots either left the service or indicated that that they would leave. TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the motion?

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that Townsville is becoming an important Defence Force base and that proper facilities must be provided. I am very pleased to see these limited facilities being provided. I hope we never go back to the stage where the facilities that are provided do not relate to those in the civilian community, because if that gulf between civilian standards and Defence Force standards continues to widen then the loss rate from the Services will continue at record levels.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Introduction

The Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill 1988 gives effect to the first of what will be a wide-ranging series of measures to reform government business enterprises. These measures reflect the Government's continuing commitment to improving the efficiency of the federal public sector. That commitment was enunciated in the Australian Labor Party's 1983 policy statement `Labor and Quality of Government'. It was reflected in the Government's December 1983 policy paper, `Reforming the Australian Public Service' and again in the `Policy Guidelines for Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises' tabled by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in October 1987.

The policy guidelines established processes for better defining and expressing the objectives which enterprises serve and against which their performance could be evaluated. They also acknowledged the need to reduce the extent of government controls over their operations. The thrust of the guidelines is to devolve responsibility-to let managers manage-with appropriate accountability for results. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in the 1988 May economic statement, referred to this Government's pursuit of wide-ranging policies directed at improving the operation of domestic markets and the efficiency with which resources are used. As part of this, the Government is conducting fundamental reviews of the principal Government business enterprises. The first results of this task were seen in the statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) on 25 May 1988, `Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises'. Under the proposals spelt out in the Minister's statement, the emphasis will be placed on planning and accountability for results.

Enterprises will be expected to plan in advance their major financial and operational goals and the measures required to achieve them, including the achievement of community service obligations; to work towards pre-set financial targets; and to report on success in meeting those targets and other previously identified performance indicators. Integral to the new arrangements is the clear delineation of responsibilities between the Government as owner-shareholder, the enterprise board and enterprise management. The board and management will be largely free of government day to day controls to achieve the goals and targets set and agreed to by the Government. The reviews of individual enterprises are continuing.
Key Elements

I turn now to the Bill itself. Full details of the Bill are provided in the explanatory memorandum. Here I wish to refer to its most significant features. The Bill establishes new arrangements for the appointment and remuneration of the chief executives of the Australian Shipping Commission, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Other enterprises will be covered by similar arrangements as their reform proposals are brought forward. Each chief executive is to be appointed by the relevant portfolio Minister after receiving a recommendation from the enterprise board. Consistent with the heightened emphasis on organisational performance and accountability, and commercial practice, chief executives will not have any security of tenure. Enterprise boards will determine the terms and conditions of appointment of chief executives. Separate administrative provision will be made requiring boards to consult the Remuneration Tribunal in the course of developing remuneration arrangements, and to advise the Tribunal of the arrangements which they make.

The Bill amends the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973 to enable the Remuneration Tribunal to provide advice to the boards of enterprises. The Tribunal will no longer make determinations in respect of the chief executives of the authorities covered by these arrangements. As boards will be responsible for determining remuneration, the Bill provides that each authority will be required to incorporate in its financial statements a report on the remuneration of the chief executive consistent with the obligations placed on listed corporations by the Companies Act 1981.

The Government's intention is that boards should not be encumbered by public service terms and conditions of employment in establishing the remuneration arrangements of chief executives. To this end, the Bill provides that the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976 will not apply to the chief executives of these authorities or other enterprises to be covered by these arrangements. Other legislation relating to the terms and conditions of employment of these offices will be amended accordingly.

Boards will also be able to establish remuneration arrangements for senior executives consistent with the arrangements for chief executives. These remuneration arrangements will also apply to the chief executive of the Reserve Bank. There are no considerations for the Budget arising from these proposals.
Conclusion

This Bill is an important initiative in the overall process of the reform of government business enterprises. By enabling boards to recruit managers of high calibre and reward them appropriately, it furthers the Government's commitment to improving the efficiency of these enterprises whilst maintaining standards of public accountability. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
