DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for a number of measures aimed at fine tuning the operations of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC). Before proceeding to outline the specific measures contained in the Bill I wish to place in context the origins and role of the Commission. When this Government came to office, activity at the federal level in the area of occupational health and safety was virtually nil. This was despite the fact that Australia had an unacceptably high incident of work-related death and injury which would not be tolerated in other westernised nations.

To give honourable members an idea of the magnitude of the problem-each year in Australia 550 men and women die as a result of work-related accident or disease. In a work force of seven million this incident rate of 77 per million can be compared with figures produced in the 1984 International Labour Organisation Year Book of Labour Statistics, which showed an annual fatality rate per million workers of 22 in Sweden, 24 in the United Kingdom, 20 in Japan and 37 in the United States. Conservative estimates show that more than $6 billion a year is wasted in Australia through loss of production and associated costs because of occupational injury and ill health. The human costs, of course, cannot be quantified.

The Hawke Government came to office with a firm commitment, written into the Australian Labor Party party platform and reaffirmed in our accord with the trade union movement, to redress this situation. While occupational health and safety regulation was, and still remains, the responsibility of the States, we recognised the need for coordination of effort through an agreed national strategy. In 1984 we set up an Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to advise on the appropriate framework for such a strategy. The Interim Commission recommended the establishment of a statutory commission constituted along tripartite lines. The Government accepted this advice and the Commission was set up in 1985 following the passage of enabling legislation through Parliament. The primary role of the Commission, which has adopted as its working title Worksafe Australia, is to provide a national forum for the development of national standards and strategies in cooperation with the States.

The tripartite structure of the 17-member Commission, which includes representatives of the States, of industry and of the trade union movement, provides a consultative framework for development of uniform standards and avoidance of duplication of effort. Through its research arm, the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety, the Commission aims to provide research, testing, statistical collection and analysis and training of occupational health and safety professionals. Although the Commission has existed as a statutory body for less than three years, it has made significant progress towards the development of a national strategy.

The Commission's achievements include development of a uniform national data set of comparable statistics on the incidence and nature of occupational health and safety problems. This has been a massive task involving all State and Territory governments in the collection of uniform data with minimum disruption to existing systems and without adding to the reporting burden on employers. The Commission is also in the process of developing national standards and codes of practice, which detail preventive action required to avert deaths, injuries and diseases, on a range of issues. It has already declared codes of practice for the occupational overuse syndrome-previously known as repetition strain injury or RSI-and for asbestos. At its September meeting the Commission is expected to declare a code of practice on timber preservatives. Also, work is continuing on agreed standards, codes and guidance notes for safe manual handling, lead, noise and mechanical equipment safety. I emphasise that these standards and codes are advisory in nature-a point which has been misconstrued in some quarters.

The structure of the Commission reflects the Government's belief that improvements in occupational health and safety standards in Australia can be best progressed by cooperation, not coercion. By providing a national forum for the development of cooperative arrangements between the States, the Government aimed at laying the groundwork for the progressive shedding by the States of their complex, and often conflicting, web of regulations. By issuing advisory codes, the Commission aims to reduce rather than increase the degree of regulation concerning occupational health and safety in this country. Companies which operate across State borders can especially appreciate this point. The States are in agreement on this approach and most have moved in the past few years to replace their respective plethora of regulations with modern Robens-style self-regulatory legislation which emphasises the application of broad occupational health and safety principles at the workplace level. To complement this development NOHSC has provided significant funds for the training in occupational health and safety awareness of workplace representatives and front-line managers and supervisors.

Australia's capacity to respond to occupational health and safety problems will depend in part on the level of available knowledge about such problems. NOHSC has moved to greatly enhance our stock of knowledge by the recruitment of a number of world-renowned experts to the National Institute. These include its Director and acting Chairman of NOHSC, Dr Ted Emmett. Dr Emmett is an Australian whose work on occupational skin diseases and cancer is well recognised and who came to the Institute from Baltimore's Johns Hopkins University where he was Professor of Occupational Medicine. The Institute's Deputy Director, Dr Wai-On Phoon, also brings a wealth of international experience to the post. Dr Phoon was formerly Professor of Social Medicine and Public Health at the University of Singapore and has held a number of advisory posts with the World Health Organisation and the International Labour Organisation. The Institute's depth of expertise is further evidenced by the fact that it also has on staff a range of internationally recognised experts in fields such as epidemiology, toxicology, ergonomics and work environment.

As I have previously mentioned, the primary task of NOHSC is the development and implementation of a national occupational health and safety strategy. The commission had completed developmental work on this task late last year. Essentially the strategy involved definition of six priority areas which account for a very substantial proportion of occupational injury and disease that occur in Australia. These six areas identified for the implementation of preventive strategies were: occupational back pain; noise induced hearing loss; chemicals in the workplace; occupational skin disorders; mechanical equipment injury; and occupational cancer.

The 1984 interim Commission report had recommended to the Government that the work of the Commission should be reviewed after four years to ensure that its operations are in accord with its legislative brief. Accordingly, in September last year I decided to bring forward the review by one year and appointed a former Secretary of the Commonwealth Department of Health, Mr Bernie McKay, to conduct it. The review was requested, among other things, to report on: progress of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in achieving its objectives and functions; and measures to improve co-ordination of Federal and State governments' activity, including steps to avoid any duplication of effort and inconsistency of standards in the area of occupational health and safety. Mr McKay was also invited to propose any amendments to the Act which he considered would better promote and achieve the Government's policy in this vital area.

The review re-affirmed the role of the National Commission as the national body in the area of occupational health and safety. It also made a number of recommendations to streamline the operations of the National Commission and increase its effectiveness. The Bill before the House largely reflects the outcome of action on the recommendations of the review and has the full support of the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the representatives of all State and Territory governments on the National Commission.

All other recommendations arising from the review have either been adopted or are the subject of appropriate action by the Commission and my Department. In particular, action has been taken to enhance the role of State and Territory governments in the operations of the Commission. This approach was supported by Ministers of labour of the Commonwealth of Australia at their most recent meeting in May 1988. Ministers reiterated their support for an enhanced cooperative effort between governments leading to a more consistent and uniform approach to occupational health and safety. The meeting also endorsed the six hazards identified by the Commission as requiring priority action by the National Commission in cooperation with the States as appropriate.

The Bill gives effect to a key recommendation of the review which is to separate the functions of the chairperson of the National Commission from those of the Chief Executive Officer. I have accepted the view that it is desirable to separate the management and technical function of the Chief Executive from the broader and more public role of the Chairperson. The qualities required of a chairperson in supervising the role of the Commission and managing the tripartite relationship are essentially different from those required of a chief executive. Separation of the two positions is more normal and is in line with the top structures of other Government business enterprises and statutory authorities.

The Bill proposes this amendment and consequent changes to the composition of the Commission and its executive to incorporate the Chief Executive Officer as a member. It also makes provision for the duties of Director of the Institute to be performed by the Chief Executive Officer, or for the positions to be separately filled. This will allow maximum flexibility in appointing available and suitably qualified personnel in a field where expertise is scarce and where we must compete for such expertise in an international market.

Streamlining amendments are also made to provide greater flexibility in the composition of committees-the working level of the Commission-and to make clear the Commission's functions in the evaluation of hazards arising at the workplace. These amendments to the Act will facilitate and consolidate the significant improvements in the National Commission's operation and reflect in a practical way the Government's continuing commitment to improving the safety and quality of working life in Australia.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments have a negligible financial impact. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Punch, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Purpose of the Bill

This Bill is for an act to establish a new Commonwealth statutory authority, to be called the Australian Sports Commission. Essentially the Bill will merge the functions and administrations of the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission as they are presently constituted. The merger is an integral part of the process of streamlining Commonwealth sports administration being undertaken by this Government. The Commission will be able to operate under the name of the Australian Institute of Sport when performing certain of its functions.

The Bill sets out the objectives, functions and powers of the Commission, and those functions that will be performed, in whole or in part, by the Commission under the name of the Australian Institute of Sport. It also covers a wide range of issues relating to the management and operation of the Commission. The Bill also defines the relationship between the Commission and the Government within which the Commission will undertake its tasks.
Background

Following its election in March 1983 this Government set out to restore direction to the development of sport in Australia after many years of erratic support under the previous coalition Government. One of the first initiatives of the Government was to appoint an interim committee to report on the role, functions and responsibilities of a sports commission foreshadowed in the policy statement on sport published prior to the election.

The creation of the Australian Sports Commission in 1985 is now history and it is pleasing to reflect on some of its achievements. Since it commenced operations the Commission has addressed a variety of issues of importance to developing sporting opportunities for all Australians at the community level. A fine example of this has been the development of a major children in sport program-Aussie Sports, which although launched as recently as April 1986 has now been implemented in over 1,700 primary schools and reached over 500,000 children. The Commission has also taken the initiative in the promotion and development of sporting opportunities for other special interest groups in the community such as women through the establishment of a Women's Sport Promotion Unit, and older adults with the release of a discussion paper on veterans' sport.

The Commission has been actively involved in the drugs in sport campaign, and has established a national program on drugs in sport which has seen the implementation of a program of drug testing during training and at sporting events, and the production and distribution of information kits warning against the use of drugs in sport throughout Australia and to over 40 countries overseas. Perhaps one of its most noteworthy achievements, however, has been the establishment of an Australian Sports Aid Foundation as a public company to raise money from the corporate sector and the community at large to supplement Government funding for the development of Australian Sport. In order to maximise such support, tax deductibility on donations to the foundation was approved in June 1986. The result of this initiative has been very encouraging with over $2.3m being donated to the Foundation, and paid out through the Commission, for distribution in support of our national sporting organisations and specific sporting events, such as the defence of the America's Cup, during 1986-87.

In addition to these activities, the Commission has continued to administer the Government's major programs of sports assistance: the sports development program and the sports talent encouragement plan. In 1987-88 the sports development program provided almost $6.3m to 94 national sporting organisations and other bodies to assist with, amongst other things, administration, junior sports development programs, coaching development, travel to international sporting competition, and the drugs in sport program. The sports talent encouragement plan provides direct financial support to individual athletes and teams to help defray costs and loss of earnings associated with training and participation in sporting competitions. This year in excess of $800,000 will be made available to about 300 athletes, the majority of whom are members of the Australian Olympic team.

Following on from this last point, I would like to turn to our elite athletes and the Australian Institute of Sport. When this Government was elected, the Australian Institute of Sport was still in its infancy. There were only 183 scholarship holders in eight residential sports in 1983. Its training and competition facilities had not been completed, it was not fully staffed, and it was still in the process of developing its various coaching and training programs. As the Institute has become increasingly settled, it has been possible to build on the initial base established by the previous Government. A further seven sports have been accepted since 1984. Many of the new sports have been decentralised, and as such the Institute has been able to establish a significant presence in Brisbane with diving and squash, Perth with hockey, and Adelaide with cycling and cricket. The cooperation and assistance of State and local governments and State institutes of sport has been invaluable in this process. Smaller satellite units have also been set up in Melbourne and Sydney. These developments have given the Institute a truly national profile. In addition, the national sports program, which enables national sporting organisations-including the Australian Olympic Federation-to send teams and individual athletes to the Institute for pre-event training and preparation prior to major international sporting competitions, and which only commenced operations on a very small scale in 1982, is now an integral part of the Institute's activities. The program is used by over 50 national sporting organisations and up to 2000 athletes each year.

With its world class facilities and a highly qualified and professional administrative and coaching staff, the Institute has worked effectively towards realising its major aim of improved athlete performance. And while the international success of any individual athlete or team can be said to result from a variety of factors, the Institute has played an important role in the improved sporting performances of many Australian athletes and teams over the last few years. Together, the Institute and the Commission have contributed greatly to the development of Australian sport in recent years. The objectives of the two organisations are complementary and are derived from the broader Government objectives of encouraging increased participation in sport by all Australians, promoting equity of opportunity at the community level, and providing opportunities and support for the development of our elite athletes.

Beyond the financial support, the facilities, the technical expertise and the leadership they have offered, they have provided for a balanced involvement by government in sport. All Australians-be they high performance athletes, coaches, members of national, state or local sporting bodies, or individuals who have the opportunity to participate in community sports programs or utilise local sports facilities-have benefited from the existence of both organisations. Over the last 5 1/2 years, the activities of the Institute and the Commission have nurtured sport at all levels. The Australian Institute of Sport has been given the time and support necessary to properly establish itself. The personnel and facilities at the Institute are now second to none, and together these factors have contributed to the emergence of the Institute as a world leader in elite athlete development.

With the support of the Commission the sporting community has begun to recognise and take on the responsibility for the further development of sport in Australia. To qualify for continued assistance under the sports development program, for instance, national sporting organisations have had to adopt a more professional administrative approach, and to plan for the individual future development of their respective sports.

We have come a long way since March 1983. The sporting community has a greater appreciation of the fact that it cannot rely on government to shoulder all the responsibility associated with sports development. To its credit the sporting community is increasingly assuming that responsibility. It is showing great maturity in planning for the future. Similarly, the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission have made great advances in their relatively brief histories. They, too, have demonstrated a maturity in overseeing the development of Australian sport at all levels. Support and guidance are available to all, but in return a similar commitment to the future is expected, and encouragingly, is being made.

It is now necessary to consolidate the achievements to date, and to reassess the Commonwealth's role in the development of sport at the national level. In doing so, this Government will ensure the further improvement of an environment favourable to the continued development of sport in Australia. At the same time it must use its resources as efficiently and effectively as possible. A merging of the functions and administrations of the Commission and the Institute, and some of the sports program functions of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, to rationalise Government involvement in sport will achieve this end.
Government Announcement

On 25 September last year, the former Minister responsible for Sport, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), announced the Government's intention to streamline the Commonwealth's sports administration through the establishment of a single national sports body-to be known as the Australian Sports Commission. The new Commission will assume responsibility for the functions of the Institute and the Commission as they are presently constituted. Since that announcement, as an interim arrangement pending passage of this legislation, the Institute and the Commission have, for all intents and purposes, been informally amalgamated. As part of this process the Commission has been relocated at the Institute headquarters at Bruce, and much of the rationalisation of program and service provision by the Institute, the Commission and the Department has already been put in place. For instance, the sports talent encouragement plan, previously administered by the Commission, has been transferred to the control of the elite athlete side of the amalgamated body, while the sport for people with disabilities program and aspects of the cultural relations program concerning sporting exchanges have been transferred from the Department to the Commission.

These rationalisations, in addition to producing staffing and servicing savings, will remove the overlap and uncertainty which previously existed in Government sports administration at the national level, and will be confirmed in the structure of the new Commission this legislation seeks to establish.
Major Features of the Bill

The Bill outlines the objectives of the new Australian Sports Commission, which are to provide leadership in the development of sport in Australia; to encourage increased participation by Australians in sport; to provide support for the development of high performance athletes; to improve the sporting abilities of Australians generally; to foster cooperation in sport between Australia and other countries; and to encourage the private sector to contribute to the funding of sport and so supplement assistance provided by Government.

I would draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that the Commission will operate under the name of the Australian Institute of Sport in the performance of those functions associated with the development of high performance athletes. Much has been achieved in Australia and internationally by the Australian Institute of Sport and we want to build on this. As I have said elsewhere, at the same time, there are significant advantages in bringing the previous Institute and the previous Commission together into one administrative unit.

The Bill defines the general functions of the Commission, which include program management, the coordination of our national sporting effort, and the requirement to consult widely with the sporting community. It also outlines the functions of the Commission which will be undertaken under the name of the Institute. The Bill also describes the powers that the Commission will have to undertake its activities. These powers are largely a composite of those described in the pieces of legislation that will be repealed with the enactment of this legislation.

Honourable members should also note the powers and responsibilities of the Minister in relation to the new Commission. The Government wishes to ensure the Commission will operate within the framework of overall Government objectives and policies, and these provisions make it clear that the Commission will remain directly responsible to the Government. Coupled with the provisions allowing the Minister to issue directions to the Commission and to seek information on its specific activities, they will ensure a proper degree of Ministerial overview and responsibility.

As an additional check, the Commission will be required to submit estimates in respect of its proposed budget, and to produce an annual report, an annual operational plan, and a strategic plan tied to the Olympic cycle every four years. Each of these must be approved by the responsible Minister. Its financial affairs will also be subject to scrutiny by the Auditor-General.
Financial Impact Statement

The strategic and annual operational plan requirements are in line with the Government's commitment to overall financial management improvement within the public sector. In its strategic plan the Commission will be required to develop objectives for its programs and activities, to define performance indicators, and to regularly evaluate performance against these indicators. Ministerial endorsement of the plan will be required.

Streamlining of sports administration at the national level can be expected to result in savings in a number of areas. Already, as a result of the interim arrangements, the rationalisation of program administration between the Institute, the Commission and the Department has achieved a saving of five staff years. Relocation of all staff at the Bruce facilities has also generated significant accommodation savings.

In addition, under this legislation, membership of the Commission will not exceed twelve. This compares favourably with the membership arrangements this legislation will supersede, which allowed for up to 22 commissioners to be appointed to the Australian Sports Commission, and up to 14 members to be appointed to the Australian Institute of Sport Board of Management. The fewer board appointments will produce savings in terms of total remuneration paid to members, reduced meeting costs, and a reduced requirement for secretariat and other support services. Overall non-staff savings are expected to be in the order of $250,000 per annum.

The streamlining process is an acknowledgment of the need to control overall levels of spending. The cost of operating the new Commission will be determined annually in the Budget. For 1988-89, $27.1m has been allocated for the Commission's activities. This compares with allocations of $15.9m and $13.4m made to the Commission and the Institute respectively in 1987-88.

Under the legislation, the Commission will continue to receive funds from the private sector donated to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation-which, incidentally, will in future be known as the Australian Sports Foundation-in order to supplement public funding made available for sports development.
Priorities

I mentioned earlier that, since the interim arrangements came into effect in October last year, the amalgamated organisation had continued to operate existing programs and services. It has also continued to grapple with a number of contentious and challenging issues. Foremost amongst these, perhaps, is related to the need for the sporting community to explain to the Australian community and its political representatives the value of sport to the community and, therefore, why it is necessary to provide continuing financial support. This becomes a particular concern, given the pressures in the corporate and business sectors that, of late, have seen a reduction in the level of private funding being channelled into sport.

The Commission, therefore, will work to achieve and sustain the valuable outcomes that can be derived from sport, such as more children playing sport, assistance to coaching to improve the overall standard of sporting performance throughout Australia, the continued fight against drugs in sport, and so on. This, in turn, will mean identifying the resources available, both Government and private, and ensuring that they are directed in ways that will maximise their impact and benefit.

But increased funding is not the only requirement of sport, if it is to continue to grow. We also need a sound administrative infrastructure, particularly at the national level. We need efficient and effective management to ensure that what we spend has the most beneficial impact for Australian society as a whole. We need a unified approach to sports administration if we are to undertake the increasingly complex task that is sports development in the late 1980s. If we do not rationalise our structure in the manner envisaged, we face the prospect of failing to realise the goals we have set for sport, and failing to realise what sport can offer to all Australians.

The Government is confident that the proposed Australian Sports Commission is a new and improved organisation that will consolidate the considerable gains made by sport over the life of this Government, and allow for the continued and organised development of Australian sport into the 1990s and beyond. I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications Support and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will give effect to a number of the tax measures announced in the May economic statement and to some measures announced in last week's Budget. The May statement measures relate to income tax deductions for depreciation or special write-off of income producing plant, prepaid expenses and mains electricity connection costs; the treatment of certain dividends; the abolition of section 26aaa; valuation of live stock; and increases in pensioner rebates.

Budget measures in the Bill increase rebates for recipients of social security unemployment, sickness or special benefits, or of certain training or Commonwealth educational allowances; exempt from tax the special temporary allowance; and establish the basis for calculation of provisional tax for 1988-89.

Other income tax measures to be given effect by the Bill deal with the taxation of non-cash business benefits, debt finance for corporate restructuring, public trading trusts, expenditure substantiation rules and the gift provisions. The Bill will also amend the fringe benefits tax law so that remote area home ownership benefits receive further concessional treatment as announced.
Concessional Deductions for Income-producing Plant

In accordance with the May economic statement, the Bill will terminate most of the special deductions in the income tax law for income-producing plant. These are the general 5/3 accelerated depreciation allowances; certain 5 year depreciation arrangements for primary production plant and structural improvements; and the special write-offs for expenditure on general mining or petroleum mining plant, other than exploration or prospecting plant. Plant to which these concessions currently apply will in future be written off at effective life rates, increased by a 20 per cent loading for most plant as an incentive to investment. Effective life rates are determined by the Commissioner of Taxation and definition of `effective life' is to be developed for inclusion in a subsequent Bill.

The present Bill will also require taxpayers who wish to use the prime cost method of depreciation to elect to do so in the first year in which the relevant plant is used. These changes are estimated to produce revenue savings of $190m in 1989-90, $450m in 1990-91 and $1,030m in 1991-92, rising further for a few years then settling at an annual gain of around $1 1/4 billion in the mid to late 1990's.
Expenditure Paid in Advance

The general deductions provisions of the income tax law authorise a deduction in the year in which expenditure is incurred even where the services being paid for are provided over several years. On the other hand, the person providing the services may generally bring the income to account in the year in which the services are provided and this imbalance provides tax shelter opportunities.

The Bill will change the time of deductions for expenditure paid in advance under agreements entered into after 25 May 1988. Instead of being fully deductible when incurred, deductions for the expenditure will be pro-rated over the period during which the services will be provided, with a maximum period of 10 years. Immediate deductibility will continue to be available if all the services will be provided within 13 months of incurring the expenditure; if the expenditure is less than $1,000; or if it is required by order of a court or by law, or is in respect of salary or wages. Transitional provisions will ensure that the amendments apply prospectively. The revenue savings from this measure are estimated to be $35m in 1989-90 and $20m in subsequent years.
Dividends Paid by Tax-exempt Entities

Two measures announced in the May economic statement to prevent abuse of the intercorporate dividend rebate provisions will be given effect by this Bill. Under the first, certain tax-exempt entities will be discouraged from using innovative financing techniques by which investors receive a return on their investment in the form of tax free dividends rather than as taxable interest receipts. Denial of the rebate on dividends paid by relevant tax-exempt entities removes the distortion in the tax position of investors who would otherwise obtain unintended financial benefits at the expense of Commonwealth revenue.
Dividends Received by Private Companies

Other intercorporate dividend rebate changes will deny the rebate on unfranked dividend income received by private companies. These private companies will accrue franking credits that can be used to frank dividends passed on to their shareholders. This removes the tax deferral advantage of receiving unfranked dividends through a private company and leaves the ultimate individual shareholders in the same position as if the dividends had been received directly. Unfranked dividends that pass from one company to another within a wholly-owned company group will not be subject to the measure, nor will dividends paid under the arrangements for the phasing-out of division 7 undistributed profits tax which are required to be unfranked. These changes will apply to unfranked dividends paid after 25 May 1988, unless the dividends were declared on or before that date.
Abolition of Section 26aaa

The Bill gives effect to the proposal announced on 25 May 1988 to abolish the provision which taxes profits made on the sale of property within 12 months of purchase, leaving those gains to be taxed under the general gains and capital losses provisions. Gains arising from short term property sales will qualify for the five year notional averaging of liabilities under the capital gains provisions and may be offset against allowable capital losses. This amendment will apply to sales of property after 25 May 1988 and is expected to have a revenue cost of $5m in 1988-89 and $30m in 1989-90
Mains Electricity Connections

Capital expenditure in connecting mains electricity facilities to a property on which a business is carried on is to be deductible over 10 years instead of in the year in which it is incurred. The amendments will apply to expenditure incurred after 25 May 1988, but will not apply to expenditure incurred under a contract entered into on or before that date. The expected annual revenue saving from the measure in 1989-90 and subsequent years is $5m.
Valuation of Natural Increase in Livestock

The value of livestock on hand at the end of year of income is generally brought to account, at the option of the taxpayer, at either cost price or market value. Where cost price method is adopted, the law permits the taxpayer to select a cost price for natural increase which, for a class of livestock may not be less than the minimum cost price prescribed in respect of livestock of that class. The minimum values prescribed are substantially outdated, and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in the May economic statement that the values are to be increased for natural increase occurring after 30 June 1988, but to a level that is still less than any reasonable estimate of the cost of natural increase. A taxpayer who can demonstrate that the actual cost of producing natural increase is less than the relevant new prescribed value will be permitted to value the natural increase at actual cost. This change will have minimal effect on revenue.
Pensioner Rebate

The Bill will increase the maximum pensioner rebate from $250-or $300 for service pensioners-to $430 for both social security and service pensioners. It will also increase the taxable income level above which the pensioner rebate begins to shade-out from $6,142-or $6,384 for service pensioners-to $6,892 for both classes. These changes, which will have effect for 1988-89 and subsequent years, are estimated to cost $55m in 1988-89 and $210m in 1989-90.
Beneficiary Rebate

The maximum rebates of tax for other social security beneficiaries and certain recipients of allowances under Commonwealth educational schemes, and the levels at which the rebates begin to shade-out, are to be increased for the 1988-89 and subsequent income years. For married taxpayers the maximum rebate will increase from $430 to $600, with no tax payable on taxable incomes up to $11,059. For other taxpayers the maximum rebate will increase from $180 to $260, with no tax payable on taxable incomes up to $6,184. These measures are estimated to cost $20m in 1988-89 and subsequent years.
Special temporary allowances

Amendments will also be made by the Bill to give effect to the 1988-89 Budget proposal to exempt from income tax the special temporary allowance payable for a period of 12 weeks to a surviving social security or service pensioner following the death of his or her pensioner spouse. This change will apply for 1988-89 and subsequent years and will have a negligible revenue cost in 1988-89 and cost $5m in 1989-90 and $6m in 1990-91.
Provisional tax for 1988-89

Provisional tax is that part of the pay as you earn system designed to collect tax on non-salary or wage income within the year in which the income is derived. As such, it is generally accepted that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year. This Bill provides for 1988-89 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1987-88 taxable income increased by 12 per cent, and by applying the 1988-89 rates of tax and the Medicare levy, and the increased low income thresholds for the Medicare levy. Generally, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1987-88 assessments but rebates of tax allowed on franked dividends will be the 1987-88 rebates increased by 12 per cent. Taxpayers who estimate that their taxable income for 1988-89 will increase by less than 12 per cent, or who consider that their rebates or credits will be at a higher level, will continue to have the right to `self assess' and have the provisional tax for 1988-89 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.
Non-cash business benefits

This Bill will also implement, subject to some minor variations, the proposal which was announced on 4 February 1985 to tax non-cash business benefits, but delayed because of the priority given to major tax reform measures. This measure will address practices that became more prevalent following the full Federal Court's decision that the existing law taxes non-cash business benefits only if such benefits are convertible to cash and are in the nature of income according to ordinary concepts. There had also been an increase in the provision of non-cash benefits to induce business taxpayers to purchase items of plant or equipment. It was originally announced that the law would be amended to tax the arm's length value of non-cash business benefits, subject to certain special rules. On review a more satisfactory approach is to provide separate simple rules to deal with both these practices.

The Bill will tax non-convertible benefits provided after 5 February 1985 in the same way as benefits that are convertible into cash and which are taxable under the existing law if they are of an income nature. In other words, the existing rules that apply to the taxation of convertible benefits will be extended to non-convertible benefits. To ensure that there can be no element of retrospectivity in this revised approach, the Bill contains transitional provisions that will allow benefits provided on or before today to be taxed on the announced basis. In the case of non-cash benefits provided to induce business taxpayers to purchase items of plant or equipment or to enter into service agreements, the amendments will simply treat the portion of the expenditure that represents the arm's length value of the benefit provided as having been incurred in respect of the benefit. This will ensure that the expenditure relating to the benefit will not be deductible or form part of the cost of a depreciable unit of property. This approach, which varies the announcement, will apply only to benefits provided after today.
Corporate Restructure (Debt Creation) Rules

The Bill will insert in the income tax law rules foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 30 April 1987 against arrangements under which interest-bearing debt is introduced to finance the restructuring of related foreign controlled companies. The measures will deny interest deductions on debt used to fund the transfer of assets from one related company to another where the buyer and seller are at least 50 per cent controlled by a non-resident or related non-residents, except where there has been an introduction of additional income producing assets.

The new rules will replace administrative measures that had previously been imposed as a condition for approval of investments under foreign investment policy. While the amendments will generally apply from 1 July 1987, under transitional arrangements in the Bill, companies that are less than 100 per cent foreign controlled will not be subject to the legislation on restructures carried out between 1 July 1987 and 19 June 1988. As part of its consultative approach to new and complex tax legislation, the Government released a draft of the main operative provisions of this legislation on 20 June 1988 and called for comment from interested persons.

This initiative was well received and, in conjunction with the seminars sponsored by the Taxation Institute of Australia, has resulted in constructive submissions being made by members of the accounting and legal professions and by industry. A number of changes recommended in these submissions have been adopted so that the measures will not intrude unnecessarily into the normal trading activities of foreign controlled companies.

For example, although the earlier draft legislation was to have a 15 per cent foreign control threshold, the Government has agreed to increase the level to 50 per cent. The legislation is limited to corporate restructures, but the Government will quickly respond if evidence emerges of entities other than companies being used to circumvent the provisions now being introduced.
Other Income Tax Measures

Other income tax changes being implemented by this Bill will have negligible revenue effect. One extends for the 1987-88 and subsequent income years the range of business activities that may be conducted by a public unit trust, without it being treated as a public trading trust and therefore taxed as a company. Another eases the paperwork burden relating to claims for car expenses, by permitting certain information about car expenses to be specified in records to be retained by taxpayers, rather than in their income tax returns.
Remote Area Home Ownership Schemes

The rate of tax on trustees assessed under section 99a of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and on other categories of income subject to anti-avoidance provisions of that Act, is 49 per cent in 1988-89. The company tax rate payable in respect of 1987-88 income will remain at 49 per cent. As announced in the May 1988 economic statement, a lower rate of 39 per cent will apply to 1988-89 income. PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill is twofold: first, to establish the Australian Shipping Commission, which trades as the Australian National Line, as a public company; and, secondly, to remove statutory controls over ANL's operations. These are major steps towards implementing the reform package for ANL announced by Senator Gareth Evans on 25 May 1988 in his statement entitled `Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Enterprises'.

A major part of the Government's third term agenda is micro-economic reform. Ensuring that government business enterprises operate as efficiently and effectively as possible is a major element of this reform program. ANL provides an important transport link for Australian industry, both internationally and on the coast. Any improvement in its efficiency will therefore immediately be reflected elsewhere in the economy. But this will only occur if ANL is given greater flexibility and the ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and to take up business opportunities as they present themselves.

In 1983, I introduced amendments to the Australian Shipping Commission Act that went some way in that direction. Those amendments removed bureaucratic restraints and instilled a more commercial approach into the Line. The benefits of this approach are a matter of public record. ANL has been turned around from being a debt ridden loss maker into a profitable enterprise, regularly paying dividends and income tax. That achievement is the result of joint efforts-of the Commission, trade unions, the employees and the management.

This Bill completes the commercialisation of ANL started by this Government five years ago. The Line has long been required to operate in highly competitive markets, subject to the same taxes and charges as other operators. Incorporation will now give it the same business structure as most of its competitors. Removal of residual government controls over its day to day operations will complete the process of giving it the flexibility to compete on truly equal terms with private shipping operators. Removal of day today controls will not, however, mean any lessening of accountability.

The new company will be required to: provide regularly to the Minister for Transport and Communications strategic corporate plans for consideration and response; work towards an overall financial target agreed in advance by the Minister; ensure appropriate revaluation of its assets at least every five years, the first such revaluation to be settled before ANL's conversion to a company; and recommend a dividend annually, after consultation with the Minister.

And of course ANL will continue to report on its financial performance through an annual report prepared on the same basis as any company. In summary, ANL is being given the freedom to manage itself on a day to day basis without any second guessing from Canberra. But it will remain fully accountable to its shareholders, the Australian taxpayers, through their representative, the Minister for Transport and Communications.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill itself. The Bill will establish ANL as a company by providing for the Commission to be registered as a company incorporated in the Australian Capital Territory under the Companies Act 1981 on a day to be proclaimed. It is expected that the commencing day of the company; that is, the transition day, will be 1 July 1989, although it may be earlier than this if the memorandum and articles of association and the other elements of the reform package can be completed earlier. The approach embodied in the Bill is basically a refinement of that adopted for the establishment of Australian Airlines as a company; that is, the Bill provides for the continuity of ANL's corporate entity by deeming it to be incorporated under the Companies Act.

The main changes to the earlier approach reflect machinery refinements to ensure that ANL fully complies with public disclosure requirements of registration. These were requested by the Corporate Affairs Commission to avoid administrative problems encountered following Australian Airlines' registration as a company. The Bill provides for there to be no change in ANL's corporate entity. The Commission will change its name-to ANL Ltd-and its form immediately before registration. This will facilitate its registration as an ongoing business enterprise while conforming, as far as possible, to the registration requirements of the Companies Act. Continuity of the corporate entity dispenses with the need to transfer assets and liabilities from the Commission to a new body corporate. It ensures that all contracts, agreements and arrangements entered into by or on behalf of the Commission and which are in force immediately before transition will apply to the new company.

There should be no ambiguity about this point. ANL will change its form because of this legislation. But ANL Ltd retains the full obligations and responsibilities of the Australian Shipping Commission, and before that, the Australian Coastal Shipping Commission. Its heritage is clear. ANL remains Australia's national shipping line. The Bill provides for the Commission's capital-totalling $196,391,000-to be converted to $1 shares and for all shares in the new company to be held directly by the Commonwealth.

The Bill provides that on transition, each staff member of the Commission will become an employee of the company on the same terms and conditions as applied to his or her employment by the Commission. Entitlements such as long service and recreation leave, and eligibility for sick leave, applying at transition date will be preserved. Those staff who have rights under part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 will retain those rights. The Bill provides for the repeal of the day to day controls over ANL contained in the Australian Shipping Commission Act, effective from the time of registering the Commission as a company. This is done in the context of the other elements of the reform package which ensure proper and full accountability. Any minimum levels of control which the Government decides should remain over ANL will be specified in either the memorandum and articles of association of the new company or in the guidelines to directors.

Finally, the legislation we are proposing will make no calls on the revenues of the Commonwealth or, of itself, immediately provide additional revenue to the Commonwealth. The Bill has been drafted to ensure that the transition from body corporate to company status will be `tax neutral'. However, improvements in the performance of ANL Ltd that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of the Commission's services. I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 which is commonly referred to as the Budget debate. This is a very interesting Budget because it shows up some of the Government's priorities in regard to running the nation. I was just reading one of the letters to a local newspaper this morning and I think that letter summed up the Budget very well. The letter said that the Budget can be summed up in the words `tax the students and reduce the beer prices'. That is a summary of the Budget. It says something about the priorities of this Government. On the one hand the Government says that in order to enable education to expand in this nation it is prepared to tax those young people who go on to higher education and on the other it is prepared to reduce revenue by $400m by reducing beer excises.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the highest taxing Treasurer this nation has known in peacetime history. The taxation imposed by this Government has been absolutely enormous. This Government plundered taxpayers over the period 1983 to 1987, and we will see that continue during this year. To give honourable members some idea of the extent of the taxation that has been imposed over that period, I will refer to some calculations derived from Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. The consumer price index increased during the period 1983 to 1987 by 31 per cent; enterprise taxes in this nation went up by 50 per cent; personal income tax went up by 66 per cent; and sales tax went up by 81 per cent. Well may we refer to the Treasurer of the Keating-Hawke Government-I think that is the correct terminology these days-as `Pickpocket Paul', because when we look at the amount of the tax increase this year we find that it is equivalent to $660 for each man, woman and child. That is the level of the increase. That is the impost on Australian people this year. It will cost every man, woman and child in Australia $660 in taxation of one form or another, either personal income tax or consumer taxes. It is no wonder that people say, even those within the Australian Labor Party, that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have lost touch with ordinary Australians. It is no wonder that people are saying that living standards are dropping. It is no wonder that poverty has marched ahead under this regime. Since 1983 the number of people in poverty has increased from 1.9 million to 2.6 million. Is it any wonder, given the taxation policies on which this Government has embarked? The Government is creating in large part and in large measure the poverty that so many Australians are now faced with.

I now turn to comment on the overseas debt. In the period of 82 years from 1901 to 1983 Australia's overseas debt rose to $33 billion. Over the last five years it has gone up to $114 billion-an increase in five years of $81 billion. This Budget tells us that the overseas debt will increase by another $9.5 billion this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the rest.

—And the rest, as the honourable member says. Certainly there is every indication that that figure will be way out. In the first month of this year the overseas debt went up by $1.7 billion. In 1983 the overseas debt amounted to $2,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. They now owe $7,600. Those people who work in the rural sector and the mining sector of this great nation of ours spend four days out of five earning the money just to pay off the overseas debt. Last month the overseas debt increased at a rate of $2.25m and hour. We ought, as a nation, to dwell on that figure. Never in our history have we had that sort of level of overseas debt.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to reflect on just where the Government spends its money. I was particularly interested in looking at where the Government spends its money in Tasmania. I thought I would look at the capital works program in particular. Honourable members might think that the Government would spend its money in the poorest electorates-those electorates where people receive the lowest incomes-so that that money can generate jobs and more income for people in those poorer electorates. When I went through the Government's capital works program I found that, on average, it spends $1.3m in the 20 poorest electorates throughout Australia. I thought it would be a good comparison to look at how much the Government spends in the coalition-held seats around Australia. I found that, on average, the Government spends $1.92m. I then thought that I should compare this with spending in Labor electorates. In those electorates the Government spends an average of $3.1m-66 per cent more than it spends in coalition electorates. One might think that the Labor seats would be in the poorest areas of Australia. However, when one looks, one sees that that is certainly not the case.

We have been told that we are to receive tax cuts in the future. We have not been told when, who will receive them, and how much they will receive. Will this Government be able to meet its committment to restore to people the real income levels they had five years ago? If the Government is, it will have to give a tax cut of $56 a week to the average income earner throughout this nation.

One of the themes of this Government since coming to office in 1983 has been the centralisation of power in Canberra. I will illustrate how the Government has done that in financial terms. The Commonwealth's own purpose outlays have increased by 19 per cent in the period since the Labor Government came to power, whereas payments to the States have actually decreased by 19 per cent. What we find is a shift in the economic power base of this nation, away from the States and into the centralised bureaucracy in Canberra. When we look at the Commonwealth's taxation increases we find that they have gone up by almost 75 per cent over the last five years. However, the State average for general revenue grants has gone up by only 55 per cent. When we look at my State of Tasmania we see that general revenue grants have gone up by only 45 per cent. What a disgrace it is to have in power a government which wants to take control of the money available to people; it wants to centralise that control in Canberra.

Let us look at local government. What has been happening with local government is quite topical at the moment because of the referendum issue. Let us see how this Government really gives recognition to local government. In 1982-83 two per cent of personal income tax collections were returned to local government. Under this Government that percentage has now been reduced to 1.7 per cent. Road funding moneys peaked in dollar terms in 1983-84. They have remained the same ever since. In this Budget the Government has cut the budget for local government by $50m-this is the recognition it gives to local government. On the one hand the Government wants to write in recognition of local government in the Federal Constitution and on the other hand the Federal Government wants to cut the money it gives to local government. If we continue the theme of centralising power we find exactly the same thing occurring in regard to referendum questions No. 1 and No. 2 in particular. These questions involve giving more power to the Prime Minister and reducing the power of the Senate.

In my State of Tasmania there is another issue which is of great concern to us. I refer to the taking over of State powers in regard to land use matters. The Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests has dragged on for almost two years. What is going on is that this Government is locking up much of the valuable resources of the State of Tasmania and preventing the State from actually generating revenue. Maybe there needs to be developed the concept that as the percentage of land locked up by the Federal Government decisions increases there should be a reduction in the taxes paid to the Federal Government because of the revenue forgone from that land being locked up.

Not only do we see this Government centralising power in financial terms and constitutional ways and takeover of States' powers but we see it weakening the poor and the lower middle income earners in this nation. Pay as you earn tax receipts have risen by 13.8 per cent. As I mentioned before, these people are being driven below the poverty line. Under this Government 700,000 people have moved under that line. Unemployment, for many people, now extends for over one year. Child poverty has been on the increase. With the Treasurer offering to give us tax cuts in the future we might well refer to him as the person who has taxed the shirt of all Australians and is now promising to give back the buttons in 12 months time. I say to the Government that those lower middle income earners will not see that as fair or just.

I now want to make a few comments in regard to the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. Firstly, I make a few comments in reference to what the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) raised in the other House not so long ago. He referred to bipartisanship in regard to Aboriginal affairs, and indicated that it went out the door last Tuesday. I want to say to the people of Australia and to the people listening to this debate tonight that bipartisanship went out in 1982-83 when the Labor Party broke bipartisanship and pursued a course on national land rights. Ever since then the coalition has been interested in a bipartisanship approach to the matters faced by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this nation, but it has not been possible to achieve that. The Government ought not to promote the idea that it was the coalition that broke bipartisanship. It was not.

We welcome the Government's moves in adopting the coalition's long-held view that health, housing, education and, in particular, employment opportunities should be increased for Aboriginal people. We believe that there is a great need for Aboriginal people to be secure in their identity and their self-esteem and to be strong in their family heritage. We believe that only if Aboriginal people are strong in their identity and their family heritage will their culture, which has a special place in Australia's heritage because of its uniqueness, also have a special history and status as our indigenous culture. We welcome the Government's change of heart to focus on those very basic needs which are so important to the Aboriginal people.

We also welcome the expansion of the community development employment projects scheme. This scheme was started by the coalition in the late 1970s. It is a scheme which actually sets a trend in Australia. May I advocate for the second year that it would do well for the rest of Australia to look at that scheme, under which Aboriginal people forgo their unemployment benefits, have them paid in the general community and then work to receive payment of those benefits. The Aboriginal elders and leaders in these communities have set a standard for the rest of Australia. It would be an excellent idea if the Government would turn its attention to implementing that scheme throughout Australia for those people who are unemployed.

Finally in regard to the Aboriginal affairs area, I wish to refer to the $2.6m which has been allocated to a public awareness campaign-up from $700,000. In the past all it was used for was to propagate the propaganda on whatever the Government wanted. What we see coming up in the near future is a treaty with the Aboriginal people. There is no doubt in my mind that this money will not be used for the benefit of the Aboriginal people. It will be used for the benefit of the Labor Party to promote its own idea of a treaty. This Budget is not a Budget to be proud of. As this year unfolds I believe that many Australian families will realise that this Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's peacetime history.
