It seems to me that our economy has a similar parallel in that this Budget seems to be relying unduly on the performance of other economies. Much has been said in this debate about that.

I turn to some specific items. Interestingly enough, the first of them is one that the honourable member for Dobell spent some time on at the end of his speech-and that is the question of employment and training programs. We have had a major report from the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs. The Government has had that report for several years now and it has commissioned several reviews of the report. It has agonised over that report and particularly the problems of long term unemployed. We have had reviews of reviews, paper after paper, evaluations of evaluations. We have also had name change after name change. There has been a massive waste of taxpayers' funds. We know the notorious example of Priority One-Young Australia, but there have been others in this area and in the end there has been no real help to the long term unemployed in gaining skills and jobs.

The shadow Minister for employment, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), has observed that the average duration of unemployment under the Hawke Government has leapt from 33.3 weeks when it took office in March 1983 to 51.6 weeks in July 1988. The Treasurer says that this Budget brings home the bacon, but it certainly does not do so for almost one in five young Australians who cannot find work. Also, we have a situation now in which there are 127,000 adults aged between 21 and 54 who have been unemployed for longer than a year and 90,000 young Australians under 21 who also have been unemployed for longer than a year. There is not very much bacon for them in this Budget or, indeed, in any other aspect of the Government's performance.

In this Budget we have a new name for what looks like, and I am sure is, a combination of old programs. New Start is aimed at the 21-to 54-year-olds who are long term unemployed. However, each component of New Start already exists. The Budget does not introduce any new programs-it alters the mix a bit and puts a new name on the totality of programs applying to this particular group of unemployed. New Start is the name used to cover that totality. I ask the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) when he responds, whether in this debate or during consideration of his Department's Estimates, to tell us why the Government has done this. Why has it coined a new name for old programs? Is it just to make people think that the Government is doing something? Has the Government evaluated these programs? They are well enough known and they have been in existence long enough to be evaluated adequately. The Kirby report and all the other reviews to which I have referred could have made that evaluation. The Bureau of Labour Market Research, which this Government abolished, had done some evaluation and would have done more if it had not been abolished.

What are the results of the evaluations that have been done? More than half the extra places that have been funded in this Budget will be of a wage subsidy kind. The evaluations that I have seen are quite positive and I am not for one moment arguing against wage subsidy programs. However, I am interested to know why the Government has given them preference. I want to know what evaluations led the Government to this preference because in recent years the Government has been redirecting support away from wage subsidy programs towards training programs. Why has there been a change? There may be a good reason but those of us who are interested in these programs-and I see the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) is in the chamber; he has had an interest in this matter for as long as I have, which is many years indeed-would like to see the evidence. Then perhaps we could evaluate why the Government has made this change. It may be right, but on the face of it, it is not obvious that it is. What the Government has done certainly represents a change of direction and I suppose the Government is not prepared to admit that it might be wrong. I would like to think that we were a bit bigger than that in our concern for the unemployed. We are moving into relatively unchartered waters for Australia and we should have all the information on the table to enable us to examine the effectiveness of publicly funded programs.

The Government also seems to have changed its mind about compulsory work for the unemployment benefit. We all remember the condemnation by Government Ministers, particularly by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), when this concept was raised in the House by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) on 1 April 1987. Now the Minister for Employment, Education and Training speaks of `a reciprocal obligation' in the New Start program. The Minister's news release says:

Attendance at intensive DSS/CES interviews and follow-up sessions will be obligatory, unless a reason is provided; any suitable labour market assistance offered should be accepted, unless there is a good reason for not doing so, or an acceptable alternative course of action is suggested by the jobseeker.

This statement does not describe any sanctions that would be employed. When one talks of something being obligatory, one imagines that there will be some sanctions to ensure that it is carried out. The obvious sanction is deregistration with the Commonwealth Employment Service and the consequent loss of unemployment benefit. If the Government intends that, it is not saying so. If it does not intend that, how will it enforce the obligation? If the Government does enforce the obligation, in what way is this different from the concept of compulsory work or training for the unemployment benefit?

Again, I am not saying that the Government would be wrong to do that, but certainly it would be a major change and again, the Government is fudging if it is making that change and not telling us the truth. I can see some huge administrative problems and some inequities resulting from the way in which this might be handled. It is difficult to see how the elements of compulsion in this new program can be reconciled with the basic principles propounded by the Government about fairness and equity because the program would not apply equally to all of the long term unemployed.

As I said, there are 127,000 unemployed in the 21 to 54 age group who have been unemployed for a year or more and who qualify for the scheme. But there are only 50,000 labour market program places for this group, of which the old programs, now renamed New Start, will provide 25,000 places. How are these 25,000 to be chosen? What happens if more than 25,000 comply with the new requirements? Does interviewing cease? Or can the Minister offer the long term unemployed some hope? The Government now seems to have a pattern of mini-Budgets or May statements every year. Once the level of 25,000 has been reached, if the long term unemployed cooperate, will that cooperation be rewarded by the preparation of other programs or the funding of more places under this program in the May statement next year?

Related to this area is the question of the allocation of child care. The Government is talking of a new program for 30,000 new places over the next four years. Of course, 30,000 new places over four years is not very many. It is certainly better than none-in fact, it is 30,000 better than none-but it is not very many considering the timeframe. The Government is allocating 20,000 of those places for outside school hours and I believe that that is the right direction in which to go. This particular commitment will help a lot of the unmet demand for child care for people who are sole parents and who are otherwise unable to find employment. If one looks at the statistics one finds that at the end of this year there should be some 110,000 child care places in existence. By the end of the financial year 1991-92 there should be some 140,000 places. Despite this expansion, the most recent survey of persons not in the labour force-looking at the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) catalogue number 6220.0, March 1988-indicates that the inability to find suitable child care was the major reason for not actively looking for work for some 81,000 people.

So the Government's contribution is a very modest one. Sure, it has got some accolades from the financial community for its surplus, but I would be surprised, Madam Deputy Speaker, if you or the honourable member for Fraser took comfort from that. It is nice to have a Budget surplus, but still, even on the Government's own ABS figures, there are 81,000 people for whom it is a waste of time looking for work because the kind of work available is full time and the out of school hours care facilities are not there.

So, while I commend the Government for moving in this direction-and I think that it and the previous Government should have moved in this direction earlier-the simple fact is that it is not moving fast enough. I remember very well the competition, the bidding, that went on for child care places between the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the previous Prime Minister in the 1983 election campaign. This Government has let the side down, in my view. I think the Fraser Government provided more in the way of child care than any other government had done. We in fact have not seen the Hawke Government perform as well as it promised and as well as most of its supporters expected it to perform.

The composition of the 30,000 places mentioned in these Budget Papers also marks a shift in the emphasis in the type of child care provided by the Commonwealth. Whereas the emphasis of the 20,000 places commitment was on providing additional centre-based and family day care places, this new commitment concentrates more on the provision of outside school hours places, which represent 67 per cent of the places allocated in this Budget. So in fact the emphasis on child care for the children of school age dovetails very well with the commitment for the new scheme called jobs, education and training, which inevitably becomes JET, aimed at increasing the work force participation of sole parents with school age children. All of this represents a step in the right direction, but one cannot help thinking that even more could have been done to allocate more child care places.

We heard references by several people to the reduction in the price of beer. One of the reasons tax on low alcohol beer was reduced was to induce people to drink that rather than full strength beer. I think we all recognise the social importance of that. But to reduce the tax on full strength beer as well appears to be a nonsense in terms of motivating people to drink low alcohol beer. Really, the reason it was reduced was to ensure that the Treasurer's prediction of an inflation outcome would be met, because it impacts favourably from that point of view on the consumer price index because of the weighting that is given to beer. I would have thought that if the Government were absolutely committed to the symbolism of its surplus-that particular figure that it has chosen-it would have been better to have allocated more child care places or to have spent money in some other area of social need rather than to have reduced the price of full strength beer. But these are the sorts of commitments that the Government felt it had to make symbolically.

I want now to come to some comments made about the Budget with which I agree. The first of those was by Julian Disney, who is the President of the Australian Council of Social Service. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 August he is reported as having welcomed some aspects of the Budget and he is quoted as saying:
At a time when there are so many low-income Australians, there should have been a great commitment of funds in the areas of employment, training programs.
He said:
Expenditure will still be cut and housing assistance will still be lower.
The article then went on to say:

Mr Disney said the creation of 30,000 extra child-care places was a substantial improvement but the funding for that was partly made up for by a lower commitment in the employment and training programs area.
The same newspaper article reports the views of Mrs Ann Young, the President of the Child Care Association of Australia. She said that children had missed out in this Budget. The article said:

She said family day-care funding had been indiscriminate and not regulated, which had led to an appalling safety record and that the 30,000 extra child-care places to be phased in over the next four years had to be quality places.
Mrs Young said all funds should have been directed in to the family assistance package increase, unless quality day care could be ensured.

I am sure most of us would agree about the importance of quality day care; yet I cannot see in the Budget documents assurances that that will indeed be striven for. I hope that the Minister responsible will give attention to that matter. Otherwise the child care places themselves are of no value.

My last comment relates to the question of a national language policy. There is some commitment by the Government to this area, but it is inadequate. We recall that $28m was removed from the general English as a second language program in the 1986-87 Budget. It has never been restored. Any of the funding that has been channelled back through Commonwealth or State sources is subject to ad hoc annual decisions. This affects children born in Australia who are not fully competent in English. I commend the Government for the fact that it now provides proper programs for teaching English as a second language for new arrivals, but many of the children of those who arrived as adults are still suffering.

In the light of the immigration debate it should be obvious that this is a matter that requires major attention. When we come to the estimates for the appropriate department. I will say more about this question of a national language policy. I believe it is one of the most important things for us socially, culturally and in terms of trade. We must have a program in which Australians can acquire a second language and in some cases a third language. There are at least six which can be identified as major world trading languages and there are many others which are of great importance to us diplomatically and in terms of trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) has made a number of very well-informed and thoughtful points, and I hope that the relevant Ministers, particularly the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), will take note of what he said and take into account in their policy development.

SPEECH.PARA: Many papers are tabled with the Budget, some of which are very important. Yet they tend to be neglected because of the volume of material included in the Budget itself and the importance of the many policy announcements that are made with the Budget. A new paper was published this year, Budget Related Paper No. 9, entitled Labour Market Reform: Industrial Relations Agenda. That is the subject I want to address in this speech. It is particularly appropriate to be talking about this paper because it encapsulates many of the initiatives and achievements of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who will complete his term in that portfolio on Friday.

Ralph Willis has been the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations or Minister for Industrial Relations ever since the Government was elected in March 1983. That portfolio must be one of the most difficult and demanding in the Government because it combines difficult policy issues and a constant stream of utterly complex industrial relations conflicts and crises which demand immediate attention. It is an extremely difficult task to combine crisis management with steady policy initiative; yet Ralph Willis has succeeded outstandingly in combining these two roles and in achieving great results in both areas.

There can be no Minister in the Government more directly responsible for the decline in time lost through industrial disputes during the last 5 1/2 years than Mr Willis. The figures speak for themselves. In 1982, the time lost per 1,000 workers throughout Australia was 2,200 days. That was the year before the Labor Government took office, and a year in which the Australian economy went into severe recession. In the year before that, the time lost per 1,000 workers was 4,200 days. Yet during the years of recovery, when the economy has been growing strongly, time lost through industrial disputes has been low and has remained low. For example, the number of working days lost in the last full financial year for which figures are available, that is, 1986-87, was 1,100 per 1,000 workers-only just over half the level of 1982.

Many factors have contributed to this nationally important achievement, but much of the personal credit must go to the Minister for Industrial Relations for he has been centrally responsible for the administration of the prices and incomes accord between the Government and the union movement, which has set the framework for industrial relations throughout the past 5 1/2 years. The Minister for Industrial Relations has extraordinary skill in negotiation which is widely recognised and acknowledged by both unions and employers. He also has a fine capacity for rigorous and thorough analysis, for careful evaluation of alternatives, and for taking decisions after thorough consideration.

The accord has provided the framework within which there has been wage moderation, and which, therefore, has provided one of the fundamental requirements for growth in employment. The Government's most important achievement since winning office has been the growth in the employment of well over one million people, and wage moderation has been the most important factor in facilitating that growth. The Minister for Industrial Relations, in conjunction with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other colleagues, deserves much credit for that vitally important employment growth.

The paper on labour market reform outlines both achievements and plans for the labour market and industrial relations in Australia. The hallmark of the Government's industrial relations reforms has been consensus. The characteristic of every aspect of industrial relations since the Hawke Government was elected has been tripartite consultation and negotiation. Broadly, the Government's goals have been to increase economic security, freedom and justice-and they remain the Government's goals. Every individual and group seeks security. Economic growth, full employment, price stability and the improvement of living standards are essential elements in the achievement of personal and collective security.

Labour market policies are important for all these goals. Wages provide the essential income for economic security, and wage settlements are used to ensure a fairer distribution of income. The paper on labour market reform takes up the themes of promoting industrial harmony through the industrial relations system, the promotion of increasing skills in the work force through educational and training arrangements, the restructuring of awards to provide incentives for training and productivity growth, and the value of encouraging widespread participation in decision making.

The Government's main instrument for labour market reform has, of course, been the prices and incomes accord, the value of which has been demonstrated in practice and clearly recognised by commentators and scholars who have examined the performance of the Australian economy during the past half dozen years. There can be no doubt that the accord has contributed to the rate of economic and employment growth, to increased competitiveness, to the drop in the level of industrial disputes, and to improvements in the social wage.

The first stage of the accord involved uniform wage changes throughout the work force. Now the emphasis is on labour market flexibility, aimed at trying to remove rigidities and archaic practices which reduce efficiency and opportunities for improvement or application of skills. For example, many traditional forms of work organisation rigidly define job and trade roles. Many of these rigid distinctions are no longer appropriate. They prevent the most directly effective linkage of skilled people and new equipment. They do not make full use of workers' talents, skills and potential and therefore they reduce job satisfaction. Some of these traditional forms of work organisation are embedded in awards, so it is important to restructure awards to reflect the new technological and organisational realities.

One of the central elements of the labour market reform package is the emphasis on award restructuring. It includes, for example reducing the number of job classifications, thus reducing the potential for demarcation disputes. For example, there are over 700 separate job classifications in the three awards covering the textile, clothing and footwear industries. Many of those classifications are obsolete and some even relate to production methods used in the nineteenth century. Similarly, the metal industry award has 348 separate job classifications, many of which have simply been added to the existing award over its 70-year life. Award restructuring must include the removal of obsolete classifications, a reduction in the number of classifications, the broadbanding of a range of jobs under appropriate single classifications, and the establishment of links between training, skills and wages which enable employees to have a career path through to more highly paid jobs.

Ideally, a comprehensive award restructuring process involves preparing an entirely new award based on contemporary and clear language and including statements on the employees' rights and obligations, on the type of skills required at each pay level, and on progression from one level to the next, based on specified standards of competence.

Of course, there is likely to be some resistance to some of these changes, because many of the work structures have been in existence for a long time and people are used to them. Nevertheless, relinquishing traditional craft-based attitudes and jealousies and replacing them with structures which reflect contemporary technological and organisational arrangements is obviously important to maximise both the effectiveness with which people are able to work and their satisfaction on the job.

Another element of labour market change that is well advanced is the introduction of reforms to the industrial relations system. The Industrial Relations Bill was passed in this House at the end of the last session and is about to be debated in the Senate. The Bill establishes the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to replace the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The new Australian Industrial Relations Commission will have wider scope and greater powers for carrying out dispute prevention and settlement activities. There is particular emphasis on the place of non-legalistic dispute settling procedures.

The new Commission will be required to consider the interests of the parties as well as the Australian community, including the state of the economy. Grievance procedures will be recognised and encouraged. The new Commission will have powers to settle demarcation disputes and it will have discretion to allow the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to attempt to settle such disputes. The place of negotiation of wages and conditions in individual workplaces is recognised, and closer coordination between Federal and State industrial relations systems is encouraged.

Another feature of the Industrial Relations Bill is that it will encourage union amalgamation. With over 300 registered trade unions, many of them very small and predominantly craft-based, there is a great potential not only for demarcation disputes but for inefficiency and delay in processing wage claims. The Bill facilitates speedier amalgamation by allowing simply a majority of members voting in an amalgamation ballot to decide the issue and removing the requirement for a minimum number of votes before a ballot can be settled. These changes will also encourage the move which the ACTU is aiming for-larger industry-based unions.

The existing Conciliation and Arbitration Commission already embodies policies for improving productivity through the wage system in its national wage case decisions. For example, the new structural efficiency principle requires that wage increases be conditional on a formal commitment to cooperate positively in a review of award structures, and this will enable a concerted attack on outdated structures. To assist with the preparation of the environment for award restructuring, the Department of Industrial Relations is involved in a stocktake of current industry arrangements, including award structures, existing work and management practices, and training requirements. As a result of that research, areas that are most in need of reform are being identified and ways for making those reforms are being proposed. For example, a national conference is being organised for clothing union officials to examine award restructuring. The Government is also helping timber unions to hold a similar national conference. This approach emphasises the value of both education and consultation. In the vehicle industry, the Government is assisting both management and unions to conduct plant by plant joint seminars for shop delegates and middle management to introduce the concepts of award restructuring.

The Trade Union Training Authority has also allocated officers to assist in these kinds of educational programs. The Government is managing and part-funding overseas study missions by both employer and trade union representatives from the metal and vehicle manufacturing industries to study occupational classifications, work organisation and training and accreditation arrangements with other countries.

A particular problem in the area of education training is the wide differences in training systems and curricula in the various States and Territories. Of course, there have been many Commonwealth initiatives aimed at reform of the education and training system. These include the introduction of a traineeship system which flowed directly from the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs-the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) referred to this in his speech-that was established by the Minister for Industrial Relations. There are now 20,000 traineeship positions bridging the gap between school and apprenticeship in the training system. Youth training and adult training programs have also been introduced. There has been a shift from employment creation to training programs. The number of higher education places has been increased by 67,000 since 1983. There have been substantial capital works at technical and further education institutes, one of which I am very glad to see being built in Canberra with the strong support of both the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) and me. The system of unemployment support and educational allowances has been rationalised to reduce the incentive to drop out of school and to increase the incentive for training and education.

Labour market reform also includes the stimulus given to industrial democracy at the workplace. One concrete achievement was the joint statement on participative practices agreed to between the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and published earlier this year. Agreement in an area like this, where controversy is involved, is a significant and important achievement and another example of the Minister's capacity for sustained conciliatory work leading to an important outcome.

Another paper, which deals with encouraging industrial democracy and the sharing of profits and growth, was published in March. This paper addresses such matters as supporting schemes to enable employees to share in the benefits of improved productivity and higher profits and encouraging incentives has been the establishment of the national occupational health and safety system. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, which was established in 1985, is a landmark in providing the structure for steady improvements in workplace safety and health. Recently that Commission and the labour Ministers' conference identified six national priorities for occupational health and safety. These six are the prevention of occupational back pain; noise induced hearing loss; chemicals in the workplace; occupational skin disorders; prevention of mechanical equipment injury; and occupational cancer. Those six forms of injury or sickness are amongst the most damaging in Australian workplaces. For instance, three out of four people suffer from work related back pain at least once in their lifetime, and about $225m a year is paid in back pain-related compensation payments. It is also estimated that up to 500,000 workers suffer from noise induced hearing loss. These are shocking figures and it is therefore particularly important that attention be paid to the prevention and treatment of those forms of injury and ill health.

A major initiative relating to the assessment and control of chemicals in the workplace is the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme. The steady reduction in repetition strain injury in the last three years is one concrete example of what can be achieved when concerted attention is placed on every aspect of a common occupational injury.

These initiatives are in sharp contrast to the simplistic stance of the Opposition, which advocates only and solely labour market deregulation. Such a doctrinaire approach is a recipe for disorder and exploitation. The removal of minimum standards would eliminate one of the major forces for conflict resolution, orderly wage settlement and improvement in training opportunities and the work environment. The approach of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia is simply silly and ignorant. No unions agree with it and many employers oppose it.

These examples in no way comprehensively describe the past or planned proposals for reform of the labour market which are outlined in Budget Related Paper No. 9, nor do they adequately illustrate the Minister's achievements. But they give a clear indication of the range of issues which the Minister has taken up on behalf of the Government during his term as Minister, and the extent of improvements which have occurred and which are planned. The outcome of all these changes and processes is already greater security, more freedom and improved social justice for everyone in the Australian work force. The proposed reforms will contribute ever more towards those goals of security, freedom and social justice.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Whipstick Gold Mining and Development Company Ltd-Family Heritage Book Co.-Pensions-Land Rights News-CSIRO: Science Funding-Illiteracy-Victorian Football League: West Coast Eagles-East Timor

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mrs Kelly) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight about the activities of the Whipstick Gold Mining and Development Company Ltd. Whipstick is a family company with three directors and a company secretary, all of whom are related to each other. It has a paid up capital of $12 and undertakes gold mining. It has two leases near Dunolly in Victoria, one of one hectare and one of 5 hectares. That in itself is not all that remarkable. What is remarkable is that the company secretary has a long and extensive criminal record dating back to 1956. In 1984 he was sentenced to a four-year gaol term for the production of amphetamines. Perhaps that in itself is not all that remarkable, except for the fact that this $12 company, with a secretary with a criminal record, has received a half a million dollar loan from the Victorian Economic Development Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have a situation where a man with a $12 company and a long and extensive criminal record, walks out of gaol, goes to the Victorian Economic Development Corporation and gets half a million dollars to set up a gold mining business. The amphetamine production, which this man was charged for, was very extensive. The Age of 22 March 1984 stated:
Chemicals seized from the Campbellfield property in 1981 were sufficient to produce 8 million doses of amphetamine sulphate.

It is not all that difficult to produce amphetamine. What is difficult is getting hold of the reagents necessary in the production. One of the reagents that is particularly difficult to get hold of is cyanide. Today I rang two chemical production companies and asked about the availability of cyanide. I was told in both cases that there was no way an individual would be able to procure cyanide; it would have to be a company with a valid reason and an authority from the Poisons Advisory Committee. That is where this grubby activity of the Victorian Government is most disturbing. Because of the cover and the credibility given to it by the Victorian Economic Development Corporation loan, the Whipstick Gold Mining and Development Company Ltd has now applied to the Poisons Advisory Committee to procure and hold cyanide.

Cyanide is an essential part of gold production. However, this type of cyanide is not the same as that used in amphetamine production. I spoke to an inorganic chemist today and asked whether it would be possible to convert the two. I was told that any person with a reasonable knowledge of chemistry would have no difficulty in doing that. The Sun of 22 October 1981 reported on the chemical amphetamine factory of the person who is now the company secretary of Whipstick. It stated:
The workmanship and the professionalism in setting up the operation is completely different to what has been experienced by the drug bureau in the past.

So said the prosecuting policeman. We now have a situation in which a man can walk out of gaol after a four-year gaol term and, already possessing a long criminal record, can procure a half a million dollar loan from the Victorian Economic Development Corporation with no investigation into his background whatsoever. He is able to use a $12 company and six hectares of pegged out mining leases to make application for a reagent necessary in the production of amphetamines.

I find this whole thing extremely disturbing. Given the possibility that cyanide could be made available to a man with this record, given the involvement of the former company secretary in the clandestine drug manufacturing activities, I call on the Victorian Premier to order an extensive investigation into how this happened, the nature of the Government's involvement in such an enterprise and how, conceivably, management practices by the Victorian Government would be so sloppy as to allow such a thing to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year, I raised in the House a matter regarding the Family Heritage Book Co. In a skilfully worded letter, the company attempts to portray the fact that it has some unique facts about a person's family heritage. After raising this matter, my office received many telephone calls from people who had ordered the books for their relatives. The sad fact is that the elderly or widows fall easy victim to this marketing. Indeed, the cases brought to my office confirmed this general trend.

SPEECH.PARA: I wrote to the company on numerous occasions and received no written reply and, in many instances, I mailed books back for people in the hope that they would receive their money back. The number of complaints then declined. This year, the company is at it again. A constituent has received a copy of a letter from Family Heritage Australia Pty Ltd, 23-27 Marquet Street, Rhodes in New South Wales.

The lady was informed that she would receive a new `world registry' of her family name using a highly sophisticated network of computer sources in Canada, the United States of America and Australia. Honourable members will be amazed to learn that the company has also sent a letter to me offering the same information about my family. The fact is that the company new appears to have gone international. The letters sent to the Bundaberg area have a return address in Sydney. However, I have been informed that in New South Wales some of the returned envelopes are to be sent to a William Foreman of 3699 Ira Road, Bath, Ohio 44210, United States of America.

I said before that the letter is skilfully written because it attempts to convey that people will receive more than they actually do. The book itself contains some very general information which could apply to any family. It does, however, using either a telephone book or the electoral roll, compile a list of people with, using my case, the name `Courtice'. It is dishonest to the extent that not all of these people are family related. In the case of women particularly, it is a ham-fisted and clumsy attempt at establishing a family tree.

There is a great deal of interest these days, particularly this year in our Bicentennial, in tracing our family histories. This company preys on that curiosity by providing nothing more than a generalised account. In view of the fact that this company is now international, I intend to refer the documentation to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, to see whether the material contravenes any Federal laws in respect of advertising.

Certainly, the Queensland Minister, Mr Lester, is aware of it and has issued a number of warnings to consumers. The Bundaberg branch of his Department was very co-operative last time there was a general disquiet about this book. I call on people in Bundaberg who feel they have been misled to contact my office or the Consumer Affairs Department in Bundaberg to provide assistance in getting back moneys outlaid.

There is another consumer issue related to this type of matter. It refers to the small claims tribunals in each State. There appears to be growing evidence that once decisions are made against a person or company, there is a tendency towards non-compliance. As a result, the consumer is still no better off and the offending company is able arrogantly to ignore the ruling. I believe that the next meeting of Federal and State attorneys-general might care to re-examine this whole question. This matter is of increasing concern given the expansion of firms like Family Heritage into international agencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the Budget and recent changes introduced by the Government to the pension income test, there are many thousands of Australian pensioners who are desperately concerned about their capacity to maintain some semblance of financial independence in their retirement. I must emphasise that the Opposition is not against stopping exploitation of the pension system but the unfortunate fact is that the Government's proposed changes will in effect create two classes of pensioners-those who have been sensible and have gone into managed market linked investments as distinct from those who are rich and wealthy, who can stand alone and whose investments may be in real estate or the stock market.

SPEECH.PARA: The effects of the Government's changes are quite straightforward. The changes are retrospective. They will affect those who have been in schemes for up to the last 10 years and who thought that they were entering into schemes which had the support of government. They were advised by management consultants who in turn had been advised by government that these schemes were appropriate. They are now told that the basis upon which they entered those schemes is no longer the position and that there will be significant changes to the income test in respect of the income which those people may generate from market linked investments. Therefore, the effect is that those who are smart enough to go outside the system and do their own thing will be subject only to the existing income test. They will not lose their pension and their fringe benefits, whereas those who have gone into market linked schemes and have taken the advice of management consultants will be the real losers.

On a number of occasions the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has said that he is out to get the fat cats. He is out to get those whom he says are unfairly living off the system. Let us look at the reality and take as an example a female aged 63 who has worked for 16 years for a large company. Upon retirement she receives a superannuation pension of $2,040 a year or $39 a week. She also has a lump sum superannuation payment of $22,834 or $55 a week. Under the new rules she will now be denied the ability to protect herself against inflation through any type of reasonably stable investment. In fact, she will lose $27 a week of her pension plus all her fringe benefits which are estimated, depending on which State she happens to live in, at between $20 and $50 a week. The only way this so-called rich lady can avoid the draconian measures of this so-called working class Government is to put her precious superannuation savings into more speculative areas or through self-investment in real estate or the stock market.

The simple fact is that hundreds of thousands of Australian pensioners are too old and not able to make those decisions for their long term investments, and rightly so. Why should they be forced by this so-called working class Government to take risks with their nest eggs, the funds they have contributed to through superannuation-the savings they have made over their entire time in the work force. All they ask for in retirement is to be left alone by government. All they ask is to have stability of the regulations against which they will make the decisions. In this case thousands of Australians will be affected. The Minister claims 33,000 but I believe the figure will be substantially higher.

Many of these people have sums as low as $15,000 invested. The Minister claims that the limit will be $40,000. So what! The existing income test and the assets test covers people up to $82,000. Why should these people be the subject of attack at this time of their lives, in the twilight of their years, when all they ask for is financial security and independence? These people are not botting on the system. These are the people who have worked Australia through the Depression and the Second World War. All they ask of this nation is a fair go which has been denied to them by this Government which is claiming once again that a saving of $18m made in this way is the way to financial probity. In fact, all it is doing it ensuring that hundreds of thousands of Australian pensioners reach the stage where they no longer accept the word of this Government on anything relating to their financial independence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the House that an award has been given to a newspaper called Land Rights News. Land Rights News is a publication of the three Northern Territory land councils and has won a special citation from the United Nations Media Peace Awards which will be presented by the Governor-General in Brisbane on Saturday night. I congratulate the editors of Land Rights News-Pat Dodson, the Director of the Central Land Council and John Ah Kit, the Director of the Northern Land Council-on their excellent work in producing this newspaper.

SPEECH.PARA: Land Rights News started in the 1970s as two separate newsletters for the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. As you will know, Madam Speaker, the Northern Land Council is based in Darwin and the Central Land Council is based in Alice Springs. Since 1985 Land Rights News has been in its present format-a tabloid newspaper put out jointly by the Central and Northern Land Councils with contributions from the Tiwi Land Council. The Tiwi Land Council is the land council which takes responsibility for Bathurst and Melville Islands. It now averages 32 to 36 pages per edition with the most recent being 48 pages. From earlier irregular releases Land Rights News now comes out every two months and has a print run of 22,000. The special January issue which was released to coincide with the 26 January march and activities in Sydney had 100,000 copies. This tabloid has broad reach into the Aboriginal community across Australia and is also widely read overseas-throughout the Pacific region as well as in Europe and North and South America.

Land Rights News is an essential part of setting the record straight and educating and informing non-Aboriginal Australia about its indigenous population. It is used as a reference source by non-Aboriginal people and has been adopted by the National Unions Coalition with the Aboriginal Movement as a means of educating union members about the Aboriginal struggle. The front covers are designed by Aboriginal artists as a means of promoting Aboriginal art and advertising revenue is helping increasingly to cover the production costs. It is good to see that a number of government departments now take the opportunity of advertising in Land Rights News. I have a regular advertisement in it. Many government departments are finding that Land Rights News is a positive way to reach Aboriginal communities and, interestingly, advertisements for tobacco and alcohol are not accepted. I recommend Land Rights News to all honourable members. I am happy to provide them with subscription forms if they do not already receive it.

I should point out that between 1985 and 1987 I was employed by the Central Land Council. Having had experience in working with that organisation, I commend the professionalism of the staff who have often been derided in the past because they happen to work for an Aboriginal organisation. It was my experience that they undertook their roles professionally and appropriately. It is to the credit of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory that they are able to put out such a professional journal and run such a professional organisation.

I refer briefly to the appointment of Ms Barbara Shaw to the National Women's Consultative Council. Barbara Shaw is Aboriginal, a Kaiditj woman from around Alice Springs. It gives me great pleasure to inform the House of her appointment to the Council. She is a very forthright and forceful woman. She is a very capable person who has demonstrated her capacity for work and her interest not only in women's issues and those of her people-the Aboriginal people-but also those of the wider community. I congratulate her on her appointment to the Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 8 September each year is designated Literacy Day. As the House will not be sitting on that day I take this opportunity of making a few comments about it. Honourable members may wonder why this is an important day. It is important because it is a day when we all realise what a world of difference literacy makes in people's lives. How many times a day do most of us use literacy skills without realising it-street signs, advertisements, notes, letters, newspapers, even television programs.

SPEECH.PARA: I was first made aware of the problem of illiteracy in our community when, before I became a member of this Parliament, I was the regional organiser for the Workers Educational Association of New South Wales in the Illawarra. Often people came to me because their children had approached them to help them with their homework, bringing home to them the fact that they themselves could not read or write. We conducted some courses in that area. A study conducted in metropolitan Sydney in 1976 found that almost 4 per cent of people whose native language was English did not have functional literacy skills. This means that those people are not able to read simple instructions. The illiteracy rate for people with a non-English speaking background was much higher. The personal, political and economic implications of this are enormous as the full potential of this considerable number of people is not being realised. We all need to be aware of the incidence of illiteracy and the associated problems and to work towards a more literate community. Although, I suppose, Australia does not have a great number of illiterate people on a world scale, nevertheless it is a problem throughout the world.

Recently, I led a parliamentary delegation to four countries in Africa. The problem of illiteracy there was brought home to us very strongly. For example, in Ethiopia, one of the countries we visited, at the time of the revolution over 90 per cent of the population was illiterate. When the Portuguese left Mozambique, as well as pulling out much of the infrastructure, they left a great problem of illiteracy. Illiteracy is so serious a problem in Ethiopia that every literate member of the society from the President down is engaged in training in literacy. Indeed, the President himself conducts literacy classes. As a delegation we were very privileged to visit one of the literacy training centres. I must say that as someone who for many years has been associated with adult education it was a most interesting experience.

In my own area of the Illawarra we also conduct literacy classes. Indeed, most technical and further education (TAFE) colleges in New South Wales have an adult basic education section in which a variety of courses are offered to help the adult illiterate improve literacy skills, and thus increase self-esteem and potential. In the Illawarra region there are adult basic education programs at Wollongong, Shellharbour, Dapto, Nowra, Milton, and the Eurobodalla and Bega colleges. I commend the people associated with this program, especially Margrit Stocker, who incidentally happens to be a constituent of mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Yes, she is, I am very pleased to say. She is head of the adult basic education course at Wollongong TAFE. In fact, I am very proud of the work that these colleges are doing. I recommend to my colleagues here that, if possible, on Literacy Day on 8 September, they visit their local TAFE colleges. I also make an appeal to every honourable member to recognise the problem of illiteracy in the community and to do all we can to help these people reach their full potential as participating members of our democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I sent out an invitation to all senators and all members of this House to join a new organisation called Parliamentarians for East Timor. There has been in existence in the Australian Labor Party Caucus an organisation called East Timor Forum, of which I am the convenor, and we have about 20 or 25 members. Following a visit to Portugal about four or five weeks ago, I met up with the Chairman of the United Kingdom human rights group, Lord Avebury, and the Japanese convenor in the Diet of the East Timor Forum. It was decided that it was time to form an international network of parliamentarians for East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis for our belief that such an international network was possible was the declaration signed by some 450 members of parliaments around the world three years ago calling upon the United Nations to carry out its obligation to find a peaceful, political, legal and internationally acceptable solution to the crisis in East Timor.

In our visit to Portugal we were greatly encouraged by statements made at that time by the Governor of East Timor, Mario Carrascalao, and the Indonesian Minister for the Interior, General Rudini, that East Timor should be opened up to the world. This is the first concrete sign that the Indonesians may be prepared to come to the negotiating table to bring about a peaceful and legal solution to the East Timor issue. Parliamentarians for East Timor, the new group, will support efforts by the Portuguese and the United Nations Secretary-General and will pressure all governments to support self-determination for East Timor. We are also heartened by the decision taken by the European Parliament to support the resolve of its new member, Portugal, to negotiate an acceptable solution through the United Nations. This could change votes in the United Nations in favour of retaining the East Timor question on the international agenda.

We believe that it is very much in Indonesia's interests to open up East Timor and to concede to the United Nations request for a negotiated settlement. Indonesia very much wants to chair the non-aligned group of nations but other member nations will not support its claim while human rights continue to be violated in that territory. Parliamentarians for East Timor will lobby members of the non-aligned nations to fill the chair only from countries with an acceptable human rights record. I cannot comment on reports recently in the Australian Financial Review-leaked documents from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-which indicate that the former Minister, Mr Bill Hayden, in 1983, had found the Indonesians to be erratic, hostile people to deal with. This may well have been his personal experience but I want to make it quite clear that our group is not anti-Indonesian; it is pro self-determination for East Timor. An acceptable solution requires United Nations auspice discussions between Indonesia and Portugal and an opening up of East Timor to members of parliament and Amnesty International.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
